D.  "Unarmed security guard" shall mean a uniformed Stratford Borough special police officer or a uniformed employee of a licensed security officer company or a uniformed employee of the quasi-public property who is not armed with a handgun. 
(Ord. No. 2010:06, § 1, 6-21-2010) 
5.44.020 - Excesses over the IICPA index. 
    Whenever the IICPA in any quasi-public property exceeds three (3) percent for a three-month period then the owners and/or operators of the quasi-public property shall be required to implement security measures at the quasi-public property as further described in sections 5.44.030 and 5.44.040. 
(Ord. No. 2010:06, § , 6-21-2010) 
5.44.030 - Right to cure. 
A.  Any quasi-public property experiencing an IICPA greater than three (3) percent over a three-month period shall be required to take such security measures as may be necessary or advisable in the discretion of the owners or operators of the quasi-public property to reduce the IICPA below three (3) percent during the three-month period subsequent to the finding that the IICPA for the quasi-public property has exceeded three (3) percent. 
B.  In the event a quasi-public property has failed to reduce its IICPA to three (3) percent or below, pursuant to the requirements of subsection 5.44.030.A. above, for the three-month period subsequent to the finding that the IICPA had been exceeded, then security shall be provided as described in section 5.44.040. 
(Ord. No. 2010:06, § 3, 6-21-2010) 
5.44.040 - Failure to cure. 
A.  In the event the IICPA continues to exceed three (3) percent subsequent to the three-month right to cure time period described in section 5.44.030, then owner and/or operator of the quasi-public property shall be required to provide, at a minimum, three (3) unarmed security guard patrols, or one (1) unarmed security guard patrol and one (1) armed security guard within the area of the quasi-public property that the incidents related to the calls for assistance are occurring, so long as the IICPA has not reduced below three (3) percent. The time period these individuals shall be scheduled will be determined by the Borough of Stratford so as to be most advantageous in order to limit the calls for police assistance to patrol the area of the quasi-public property where the calls for police assistance were concentrated in. 
    In the event the IICPA index is three (3) percent or more, the owner and/or operator shall be required to provide three unarmed security guards or two unarmed security guards and one armed security guard. The time period these individuals work will be determined by the Borough of Stratford so as to be most advantageous in order to limit the calls for police assistance to patrol the area of the quasi-public property where the calls for police assistance were concentrated in. 
    The borough, by resolution, may require that armed security guards be provided to patrol the quasi-public property and the armed security guards' shifts shall be scheduled so as to be most advantageous in order to limit the calls for police assistance at the quasi-public property until such time as the IICPA is reduced for a period of three (3) months to a lower level in accordance with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2010:06, § 4, 6-21-2010) 
5.44.050 - Cessation or reduction of security. 
    At the end of any three-month period, succeeding a three-month period during which the IICPA was in violation of the chapter, that the IICPA has been reduced to levels below those established in section 5.44.040, the owner/operator of the quasi-public property shall be permitted but not required, to reduce or cease providing security to levels consistent with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2010:06, § 5, 6-21-2010) 
5.44.060 - Shared service. 
    Stratford Borough police officers or Stratford Borough special police officers can be contracted through a negotiated shared service agreement with the borough for off-site employment to assist the quasi-public property owner to be in compliance with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2010:06, § 6, 6-21-2010) 
5.44.070 - Penalty. 
    In the event that a quasi-public property shall exceed the IICPA as set forth in this chapter of three (3) percent or more for a period of more than three (3) months and shall fail to implement a security plan as required by this chapter, then, for each day following the period of time during which such a security plan should have been established and implemented, the quasi-public property shall be liable to pay a fine in the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). for each day it fails to provide security as set forth in this chapter. The owners of the quasi-public property shall be jointly and severally liable for the payment of this penalty. The maximum penalty which may be assessed is one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per quasi-public property per day. 
(Ord. No. 2010:06, § 7, 6-21-2010) 
Chapter 5.48 - PAWNBROKERS, DEALERS, BUYERS OF PRECIOUS METALS, GEMS, AND SECOND HAND GOODS 

5.48.010 - Definitions. 
A.  "Pawnbroker" shall mean any person, partnership, association or corporation lending money on deposit or pledge of personal property, other than chosen in action, securities, or printed evidences of indebtedness; or purchasing personal property on the condition of selling it back at a stipulated price; or doing business as furniture storage warehouseman and lending money on goods, wares or merchandise pledged or deposited as collateral security. 
B.  "Person" shall mean individual natural person, partnerships, joint ventures, societies, associates, clubs, trustees, trusts, corporations or unincorporated groups, servants, factors or any kind of personal representatives of any thereof, in any capacity, acting either for himself or for any other person under either personal appointment or pursuant to law. 
C.  "Pledge" shall mean an article or articles deposited with a pawnbroker in the course of his business. 
D.  "Pledger" shall mean a person who delivers the pledge into the possession of a pawnbroker, unless such person discloses that he is or was acting for another, and in such an event "pledger" means the disclosed principal. 
E.  "Precious metals and gems" shall mean items comprised of gold, silver, platinum, palladium and alloys thereof, gems, coins, containing precious metals and all forms of previously owned jewelry which contain precious metals. 
F.  "Precious metals and gems buyer" shall mean a person engaged in the business of purchasing metals, gems, coins, containing precious metals and all forms of previously owned jewelry, either as a primary business or in connection with another business, from any person who is not in the business of selling precious metals as required under N.J.S.A. 51:6A-1 to 51:6A-8 including, but not limited to, business commonly referred to as "jewelry stores". 
G.  "Secondhand goods" shall mean all forms of previously owned goods, including, but not limited to: antiques, furniture, watches, china, crystal, painting, precious metals and gems, and goods containing precious metals and gems. This will not include donation centers where second hand goods are donated to a charitable organization for resale. 
(Ord. No. 2010:13, § 1, 9-20-2010) 
5.48.020 - Purpose and intent. 
    The purpose and intent of this chapter is to provide licensing and regulation of individuals dealing in precious metals, gems, secondhand goods, and pawn brokering to protect the residents of Stratford as permitted, in part, by N.J.S.A. 51:6A-1 et seq. Further, the licensing and regulating of these individuals will further assist the Stratford Police Department and others in recovering stolen goods. In addition, in regard to precious metals and gems, this ordinance shall be complied with in addition to the laws, rules and regulations as contained in N.J.S.A. 51:6A-1 et seq. and N.J.A.C. 13:47C-1.1 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 2010:13, § 2, 9-20-2010) 
5.48.030 - Registration of pawnbroker, dealer, precious metals and gems buyer with the police department. 
    Precious metals and gems buyer as defined herein or as defined by N.J.S.A. 51:6A-1 et seq. shall, prior to buying, attempting to buy or offering to buy any precious metals or gems, register with the Borough of Stratford on a form prescribed by the police department. This registration is in addition to any license required by any chapter under the Borough Code. 
(Ord. No. 2010:13, § 3, 9-20-2010) 
5.48.040 - License required; statement of license number requested advertisement. 
    No individual person, partnership, or corporation shall engage in the business of the purchase, sale or pawn brokering of and all forms of previously owned jewelry and goods without first obtaining a license from the borough. 
(Ord. No. 2010:13, § 4, 9-20-2010) 
5.48.050 - Licenses to maintain receipt book and records. 
    All persons regulated to purchase, buy, sell or pawnbroker precious metals and gems and secondhand goods to require of anyone offering to sell them merchandise regulated by this section to produce one (1) valid form of state photo identification such as a driver's license, state identification card or similar identification. They shall also sign and give to the seller a receipt for said merchandise and shall obtain from the seller the following information: name, address, sex, date of birth, telephone number, social security number (if available), and take and retain a digital photograph of the seller. 
A.  All persons regulated by this section shall maintain a record of each purchase, which record shall contain a written description and digital photograph of the merchandise purchased taken together with the seller's identification, any identifying numbers, marks or markings on the merchandise, a copy of the signed receipt given to the seller and a record of all information required under this section. 
1.  The receipt provided to the seller shall contain the following information: 
a.  The price at which the precious metals are being bought expressed as a price per ounce. 
b.  The weight of the precious metal purchased together with a full and complete description of the items being purchased. 
c.  If the item purchased is a gem or piece of jewelry not bough on the basis of weight, the price paid for the item together with a description of the item. 
d.  The name and address of the seller, sex, date of birth, telephone number, social security number (if available). 
2.  Those records shall be immediately available for inspection by any law enforcement agency and shall be maintained for three (3) years from the date of purchase. 
B.  Once every fourteen (14) days, all the businesses regulated under this section shall deliver (in person or electronically) to the police department a list of all items of bought, or pawned by the pawnbroker/precious metals and gems buyer. The delivery and format will be regulated by the police department. 
C.  No person regulated by this section shall sell, melt down or otherwise dispose of any merchandise covered by this section purchased by him until after the expiration of seven (7) business days. 
D.  No person who engages in the business of the purchase of precious metals, gems, coins or previously owned jewelry shall purchase any such items from any person under the age of eighteen (18) years of age. 
(Ord. No. 2010:13, § 5, 9-20-2010) 
5.48.060 - Penalties. 
    Violation of any part of this section may result in the revocation of the license pursuant to the rules and regulations of section 5.04.030.F. of the Borough Code regulating licensing. In addition to the revocation, each transaction is considered a separately punishable violation which upon conviction will be punishable by no less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and no more than one thousand two hundred dollars ($1,200.00) per offense. 
(Ord. No. 2010:13, § 1, 9-20-2010) 
Title 6 - ANIMALS 
Chapters: 
Chapter 6.04 - DOGS AND CATS 
Sections: 

6.04.010 - Registration and license required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to own, keep or harbor any dog within the corporate limits of the borough unless such dog shall be registered and licensed in the manner hereinafter provided. 
(Prior code § 54-1) 
6.04.020 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter the terms used herein are defined as follows: 
    "Dog" includes all canines, irrespective of sex, of more than six (6) months of age. 
    "Immediate" shall mean that the pet solid waste is removed at once, without delay. 
    "Owner/keeper" any person who shall possess, maintain, house or harbor any pet or otherwise have custody of any pet, whether or not the owner of such pet. 
    "Person" is any individual, corporation, company, partnership, firm, association, or political subdivision of this state subject to municipal jurisdiction. 
    "Pet" is a domesticated animal kept for amusement or companionship. 
    "Pet solid waste" is waste matter expelled from the bowels of the pet; excrement. 
    "Proper disposal" is placement in a designated waste receptacle, or other suitable container, and discarded in a refuse container which is regularly emptied by the municipality or some other refuse collector; or disposal into a system designed to convey domestic sewage for proper treatment and disposal. 
(Prior code § 54-2; Ord. No. 2005:04, §§ 1, 2, 4-12-2005) 
6.04.030 - Application for licenses and registration-License tag. 
A.  Every person who shall own, keep or harbor a dog or cat within this borough shall make application to the borough clerk for the registration and licensing thereof on or before the last day of March of every year or within thirty (30) days after the dog or cat shall be acquired by or come into possession of such person, whereupon it shall become the duty of said clerk to issue and deliver to such applicant a metal tag having stamped thereon the name of the borough, the year in which it was issued and the number of the license. 
B.  Said applicant shall pay therefore an annual license fee; and fifteen dollars and eighty cents ($15.80) for a nonneutered or nonspayed dog, plus all state fees due. If any owner of a dog shall submit a certificate signed by a licensed veterinarian stating that the dog has been spayed or neutered, then the annual license fee shall be the sum of thirteen dollars and eighty cents ($13.80) for a spayed or neutered dog, plus all state fees due. 
C.  Said applicant shall pay therefore an annual license fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) for a cat, plus all state fees due. If any owner of a cat shall submit a certificate signed by a licensed veterinarian stating that the cat has been spayed or neutered, then the annual license fee shall be the sum of ten dollars ($10.00), plus all state fees due. 
D.  No person shall keep or harbor more than four (4) total dogs and cats in one (1) private home. 
E.  In the event that a license has not been obtained by March 31st, a late charge will be imposed: 
1.  An additional fee of five dollars ($5.00) for April registrations. 
2.  An additional fee of ten dollars ($10.00) for May registrations. 
3.  An additional fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) for June registrations. 
4.  An additional fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) for July registrations. 
5.  An additional fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for August registrations. 
(Prior code § 54-3; Ord. No. 97:07, 1997; Ord. No. 98:22, § 1, 1998; Ord. No. 2000:14, § 1, 2000; Ord. No. 2007:04, §§ 1, 2, 3-13-2007) 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ordinance No. 2007:04 states "This will take effect with fees collected on and after January 01, 2008", referring to subsections B. and C., herein. 
6.04.040 - Record of licenses issued-Disposition of fees. 
    Said tags shall be provided to the clerk for this purpose by and at the expense of the borough. The clerk shall keep a permanent record of all licenses so issued by him or her, showing the date issued, the name and address of the owner of the dog and a description of such dog, including its breed, color and sex; and he or she shall account for and remit to the borough treasurer all fees collected under this chapter in each month on or before the tenth day of the succeeding month. 
(Prior code § 54-4) 
6.04.050 - Tags affixed to dogs-Nontransferability-Lost tags-Expiration. 
A.  Upon receipt of such license tag from the clerk, the person securing the same, or the owner of the dog, shall forthwith cause the same to be affixed securely and permanently to the collar or harness of the dog for which it was issued. Such licenses shall not be transferable from one person to another or from one dog to another, provided that, upon a change in ownership of any dog so licensed, a change in the registration may be effected upon proper application therefor to the borough clerk and the payment of a transfer fee of fifty cents, ($.50) in which case a new license shall not be required. It is unlawful for any person to remove such tag from the collar or harness of any dog without the consent of such dog's owner. It is likewise unlawful for such tag to be used for or upon any dog other than the dog for which it was issued. 
B.  Upon satisfactory proof to the borough clerk that such license tag has been lost, a new one may be supplied by him or her upon the payment of a fee of fifty cents ($.50). 
C.  All licenses so issued shall expire on December 31st of the year in which they shall be issued. 
(Prior code § 54-5) 
6.04.060 - Kennel license-Pet shops. 
A.  Every person who shall own, keep or harbor five (5) or more dogs at any one (1) time within this borough may, in lieu of the individual registration of such dogs and upon the payment of the fee prescribed below, apply for and receive from the borough clerk a kennel license. Such license, as well as the clerk's record of its issuance, shall show the payment of the fee therefor, specifying the amount, the date of issuance, the name of the person to whom issued and his or her address and the number of dogs to be covered thereby. The fees for such licenses are ten dollars ($10.00) and twenty-five dollars ($25.00) as follows: 
The annual license fee for a kennel providing accommodations for ten (10) or fewer dogs shall be ten dollars ($10.00) and for more than ten (10) dogs, twenty-five dollars ($25.00). The annual license fee for a pet shop shall be ten dollars ($10.00). No fee shall be charged for a shelter or pound. This fee is to be paid to the borough clerk. 
B.  All such licenses must have the approval of the local municipality and health authorities before issuance. The establishments must comply with the local and state rules and regulations governing operation and sanitation. 
C.  The maximum number of dogs to be maintained in a kennel shall not exceed twenty (20). It is unlawful for the holder of any kennel license to permit any dog or dogs covered thereby to run at large. 
(Prior code § 54-6) 
6.04.070 - Animal warden-Impoundment-Notices. 
A.  Animal warden. For the purposes of carrying out the provisions of this chapter, mayor and council may designate or employ, in each year, an animal warden, along with one (1) or more assistants, who along with any member of the police department shall have the power to take into custody and impound or cause to be taken into custody and impounded any dog, cat or other domestic animal off the premises of the owner or the person keeping or harboring the dog, cat or other domestic animal which is believed to be a stray, running at large, vicious, potentially dangerous, without a current registration tag on its collar, or a female dog, cat or other domestic animal in season. 
B.  Entry upon premises for seizure. Any officer or agent authorized or empowered to perform any duty under this chapter is authorized to go upon any premises to seize for impounding any dog, cat or other domestic animal which he or she may lawfully seize and impound when he or she is in immediate pursuit of such dog, cat or other domestic animal, except upon the premises of the owner, if the owner is present and forbids the same. 
C.  Destruction-Notice. If any dog, cat or other domestic animal seized as provided in subsection A., of this section wears a harness or collar having inscribed thereon or attached thereto the name and address of any person, or a registration tag, or if the owner or person keeping or harboring the dog, cat or other domestic animal is otherwise known, the animal warden or other officer shall forthwith serve or cause to be served on the person whose address is given a notice in writing stating that the dog, cat or other domestic animal has been seized and will be liable to be disposed of or destroyed if not claimed within seven (7) days after the service of the notice. Said notice may be served either by delivering it to the person on whom it is to be served or by leaving it at the person's usual or last known place of abode or at the address on the collar or by forwarding it by mail. The seven-day period shall run from the time of mailing the notice of which careful record shall be kept. The registered owner or person keeping or harboring the seized dog, cat or other domestic animal may claim the dog, cat or other domestic animal within the seven-day period by paying all expenses incurred by reason of its detention, including reasonable maintenance expenses. No redemption of any unlicensed animal shall be permitted until said animal has been duly licensed and registered as herein provided. 
D.  Notice to SPCA. The animal warden or other officer charged with the duty of sending the aforesaid notices shall, in addition thereto, immediately upon the taking and impounding of any dog, cat or other domestic animal, whether licensed or unlicensed, cause a notice thereof in writing to be mailed or sent by telefacsimile (fax), or such other commonly accepted electronic communication, to the nearest office of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (SPCA), or such other similar organization which services the borough, that the dog, cat or other domestic animal will be destroyed unless claimed by the organization or redeemed within seven (7) days of the notice. 
(Prior code § 54-7; Ord. No. 97:16, § 1, 1997) 
6.04.080 - Compensation of animal warden-Contract for enforcement. 
    The governing body of this borough may, by resolution, fix the compensation of such animal warden or any other officer charged with the enforcement of this chapter, or provide for the enforcement of this chapter by contract with any person or society, as well as provide facilities for its enforcement by its own officers. 
(Prior code § 54-8) 
6.04.090 - Hindering or interfering with authorized persons. 
    It is unlawful for any person to in any way hinder, molest or interfere with any person authorized or empowered to perform any duty under this chapter, while engaged in the performance thereof. 
(Prior code § 54-9) 
6.04.100 - Annual canvass of dogs. 
    The animal warden, if any, or such other person as shall be designated by the governing body of this borough shall, during the month of January of each year or as soon thereafter as the same may be accomplished, make a thorough canvass of all dogs owned, kept or harbored within this borough and shall report the result of such canvass, including the names of all persons owning, keeping or harboring dogs and the number of such dogs, to the borough clerk. 
(Prior code § 54-10) 
6.04.110 - General regulations. 
A.  Disturbing peace and quiet. No person shall keep, harbor or maintain any dog which habitually barks or cries between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., or which at any time by frequent barking, howling, whining or crying disturbs the peace, comfort or quiet of the neighborhood, thereby creating or maintaining a nuisance. 
B.  Running at large prohibited. No person owning, keeping or harboring any dog, cat or other domestic animal shall suffer or permit it to run at large upon the public streets, public sidewalks, public parks or in any public building or in any other public place or on any private property without the consent of the owner. 
C.  Leash requirement. No person owning, keeping or harboring any dog shall suffer or permit it to be upon the public streets or in any public places of the borough unless such dog is accompanied by a person over the age of twelve (12) years and is securely controlled and confined by an adequate leash not more than six (6) feet long. 
D.  Injury to property prohibited. No person owning, keeping or harboring a dog, cat or other domestic animal shall permit or suffer it to do any injury or do any damage to any lawn, shrubbery, flowers or real or personal property, either public or private, within the borough. 
E.  Defecation-Removal of feces. No person owning, keeping or harboring a dog, cat or other domestic animal shall cause or allow such dog, cat or other domestic animal to soil, defile, defecate on or commit any nuisance on any public street, public walkway, public park, public building or any other public property, or upon any private property without the consent of the owner. 
Any persons, excluding a blind person with a guide dog, owning, keeping or harboring any dog, cat or other domestic animal which soils, defiles, defecates on or commits any nuisance on any public street, public walkway, public park, public building or any other public property, or upon any private property without the consent of the owner, shall immediately remove all feces deposited by any such dog, cat or other domestic animal in a sanitary manner. 
Sanitary methods for removing all feces are mechanical devices such as pooch scoops, small shovels and like devices. All feces removed by the person owning, keeping, harboring or in charge of any such dog, cat or other domesticated animal shall be disposed of in a sealed nonabsorbent leak-proof container. 
F.  Vicious and potentially dangerous animals. The borough adopts and incorporates herein all of the provisions of N.J.S.A. 4:19-1 et seq. as amended and supplemented, including but not limited to, the definition of "vicious dog" in N.J.S.A. 4:19-22 and "potentially dangerous dog" as defined in N.J.S.A 4:19-23. For the purposes of this section, the terms "vicious" and "potentially dangerous" may be applied to any animal, and are not limited to a dog. 
G.  The total household pets kept or harbored by any resident inside or outside the residence shall not be more than four (4) total. This will include cats, dogs, rabbits, mammals, birds, retiles, and/or any pets or animals allowed by law in a residence. 
(Prior code § 54-11; Ord. No. 97:16, § 2, 1997; Ord. No. 2002:22, § 01, 11-12-2002) 
6.04.111 - Keeping of certain animals prohibited. 
    The keeping of the following animals within in the corporate limits of the borough is prohibited: Swine, cattle, horses, donkeys, mules, ponies, goats, sheep or any other livestock, single or in any number; chickens, ducks, geese, pheasants pigeons or any other fowl, singly or in any number; and other animals determined by the nuisance/health inspector with the advice and consent of the mayor and council. The keeping of any other animal of whatever species is to be prohibited when, in the judgment of the board of health, it is found that a public health nuisance is being maintained by the continued keeping of such animal. 
(Ord. No. 2003:16, § 01, 7-8-2003) 
6.04.120 - Sanitary requirements. 
A.  No person who owns, keeps, harbors, walks or has custody of a dog shall permit, cause, suffer or allow such dog to defecate upon, soil, defile or commit any nuisance of any kind on a public or private property without the express permission of the owner of such property. 
B.  In the event a dog shall soil, defile or defecate upon any public or private property, the owner, keeper, harborer and/or person having custody of said dog shall immediately remove and sanitarily dispose of said dog's feces and droppings deposited by such dog, which removal shall be by a shovel, container, disposal bag or any other sanitary manner. 
C.  A person who owns, keeps, harbors or has custody of a dog shall maintain such person's property in a sanitary manner so as to prevent any noxious odors, attraction of insects, attraction of vermin breeders and any other public health nuisance. 
D.  Any person or entity found guilty of violating this section shall be subject to a fine of not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00). It shall be a defense to a conviction for violation of this section if the person or entity in question has complied with subsection B of this section. 
E.  Any owner or keeper who requires the use of a disability assistance animal shall be exempt from the provisions of this section while such animal is being used for that purpose. 
(Ord. No. 94:5, §§ 1-4, 1994; Ord. No. 2007:09, § 1, 5-8-2007) 
6.04.130 - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be liable to the payment of a penalty not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment for a term not to exceed ninety (90) days, or both. 
(Prior code § 54-12) 
6.04.140 - Sale of dogs and cats by pet shops prohibited. 
A.  Definitions. 
    Animal care facility means an animal control center or animal shelter, maintained by or under contract with any state, county, or municipality, whose mission and practice is, in whole, or significant part, the rescue and placement of animals in permanent homes or rescue organizations. 
    Animal rescue organization means any not-for-profit organization which has tax-exempt status under Section 501(c)(3) of the United States Internal Revenue Code, whose mission and practice is, in whole or in significant part, the rescue and placement of animals in permanent homes. 
    Cat means a member of the species of domestic cat, Felis catus. 
    Dog means a member of the species of domestic dog, Canis familiaris. 
    Offer for sale means to sell, offer for sale or adoption, advertise for the sale of, barter, auction, give away or otherwise dispose of a dog or cat. 
    Pet shop means a retail establishment where dogs and cats are sold, exchanged, bartered or offered for sale as pet animals to the general public at retail. Such definition shall not include an animal care facility or animal rescue organization, as defined. 
B.  Restrictions on the sale of animals. 
1.  A pet shop may offer for sale only those dogs and cats that the pet shop has obtained from or displays in cooperation with: 
a.  An animal care facility; or 
b.  An animal rescue organization. 
2.  A pet shop shall not offer for sale a dog or cat that is younger than eight (8) weeks old. 
(Ord. No. 2917:05, §§1, 2, 2-14-2017) 
Chapter 6.05 - WILDLIFE FEEDING 
Sections: 

6.05.010 - Purpose. 
    An ordinance to prohibit the feeding of unconfined wildlife in any public park or on any other property owned or operated by the Borough of Stratford, so as to protect public health, safety and welfare, and to prescribe penalties for the failure to comply. 
(Ord. No. 2005:07, § 01, 4-12-2005) 
6.05.020 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations shall have the meanings stated herein unless their use in the text of this chapter clearly demonstrates a different meaning. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words used in the plural number include the singular number, and words used in the singular number include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. The definitions below are the same as or based on corresponding definitions in the New Jersey Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NJPDES) Rules at N.J.A.C. 7:14A-1.2. 
a.  Feed is to give, place, expose, deposit, distribute or scatter any edible material with the intention of feeding, attracting or enticing wildlife. Feeding does not include baiting in the legal taking of fish and/or game. 
b.  Person is any individual, corporation, company, partnership, firm, association, or political subdivision of this state subject to municipal jurisdiction. 
c.  Wildlife is all animals including domesticated. 
(Ord. No. 2005:07, § 02, 4-12-2005; Ord. No. 2011:06, § 01, 7-12-2011) 
6.05.030 - Prohibited conduct. 
    No person shall feed, in any public park or on any other property owned or operated by the Borough of Stratford, any wildlife, excluding confined wildlife (for example, wildlife confined in zoos, parks or rehabilitation centers, or unconfined wildlife at environmental education centers). 
(Ord. No. 2005:07, § 03, 4-12-2005) 
Title 8 - HEALTH AND SAFETY 
Chapters: 
Chapter 8.04 - ALARM SYSTEMS 
Sections: 

8.04.010 - Short title. 
    The ordinance codified in this chapter shall be known as and referred to as the "Stratford Borough Alarm System Ordinance". 
(Ord. No. 98:18, (part), 1998) 
8.04.020 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to provide for the establishment and maintenance of an efficient, effective and uniform police alarm system within the borough and to provide standards and regulations for various alarm equipment, devices or systems to be installed or connected with or to the Camden County Department of Public Safety Police Communications Center, so as to elicit a response or action by the police department of the borough, and to establish regulations concerning the operation and maintenance of alarm systems within the borough, reduce the number of false alarms and police and fire department responses thereto, and provide penalties upon convictions for violation of any of the provisions set forth herein. 
(Ord. No. 98:18, (part), 1998) 
8.04.030 - Applicability. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall apply to any person who installs, connects, operates, maintains, services, owns or leases any alarm equipment, device or system, including dialer and local alarms, designed to summon the police department, the fire department or any other agency or person to any location within the borough in response to any type of signal, alarm or preprogrammed, prerecorded message or recording. The provisions contained herein shall apply equally to those systems that were placed in service prior to, or subsequent to, the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 98:18, (part), 1998) 
8.04.040 - Definitions. 
    "Alarm systems" means any mechanical, electrical or electronic device, devices or systems which are designed or used for the detection of unauthorized entry into a building, structure, facility or area, or for altering others about the commission of an unlawful act within a building, structure, facility or area, or for altering others about the existence of any other condition requiring the response of police, ambulance, or fire personnel; and which emits and/or transmits any audible and/or visual and/or electronic signal or message when activated. Alarm systems include, but are not limited to: Direct dial telephone devices, both digital and tape recorded voice; panel alarms that terminate and/or report directly to the police communications center; local and/or audible and/or visual alarm systems; alarm systems that report to any commercial alarm receiving station or center; or any other type of alarm system that is designed to elicit action of or by the police department, fire department, or ambulance squads of the Borough of Stratford. Alarms systems shall further include any telephone, computer or other electronic device used or capable of calling, dialing or contacting the 911 emergency system located at the Camden County Communications Center or any other 911 emergency system established in this or any other state. 
    "Ambulance personnel" or "ambulance squad" means any one (1) or more personnel, units, or squad of the ambulance or rescue squads of the Borough of Stratford; also, any mobile intensive care unit (MICU) or any MICU personnel usually operating in support of, or in conjunction with, ambulance personnel or ambulance squads within the Borough of Stratford. 
    "Borough" means the Borough of Stratford. 
    "Borough council" means the Borough Council of the Borough of Stratford. 
    "Chief of police" means the Chief of Police of the Borough of Stratford or his or her designee. 
    "Common annunciator license" means that license issued by Borough Council of the Borough of Stratford to install and connect and to operate, control and maintain the police alarm system and to make all subscriber installations and connections thereto. 
    "Direct dial alarm" means a device that when actuated causes an electronic digital or prerecorded voice message to be transmitted, via telephone, to the police department communications center or fire department communications center. 
    "False alarm" means an alarm signal or message causing a response by police, fire or ambulance personnel when an emergency does not exist; provided, however, an alarm signal or message activated by an external source or causes entirely beyond the control of the alarm system owner or operator or their agents such as a storm or electrical failure, shall not be deemed a false alarm. Accidental alarms, malfunctions or other false activations in excess of three (3), within thirty (30) days or more than eight (8) malfunctions, accidental, or other false alarms within any twelve-month period shall be deemed false alarms. Purposeful or negligent misuse or the otherwise improper use of the 911 system shall constitute a violation if more then three (3) activations occur within any twelve-month period. 
    "Fire alarm system" means any alarm system designed to be used for the detection of fire or other conditions requiring the presence of fire personnel. 
    "Fire personnel" or "fire department" means any one (1) or more personnel, units, or companies of the volunteer fire companies of the Borough of Stratford. 
    "Local alarm" means a device that when actuated, emits an audible and/or visual signal from the premises that it is designed to protect. Local alarms may also be direct dial alarms or panel alarms. 
    "Panel alarm" means a device that when actuated transmits an electronic signal, via leased telephone circuits, to the police communications center or fire department communications center. 
    "Person" means any natural person, partnership, firm, corporation or association. 
    "Police" or "police department" means the Borough of Stratford Police Department. 
    "Police alarm system" means that system giving a visual or audio response, or both, on the control panel of the police console located within the confines of the Camden County Department of Public Safety, Police Communications Center, county personnel, including the subscriber modules, the control modules, the control cabinets, the energy pack and all necessary and accessory equipment, wires and connections therein and thereto, and any digital alarm receiving equipment, including receiver, printer, energy pack, telephone connections and all necessary and accessory equipment, wires and connections. It shall also include as far as applicable, any special telephone lines reserved for receiving voice-type automatic telephone dialer alarms. 
    "Security alarm system" means any alarm system designed or used for the detection of, or reporting of, those conditions requiring the response primarily of the police or ambulance personnel including, but not limited to, burglar, holdup, panic, and medical-alert type alarm systems. 
(Ord. No. 98:18, (part), 1998; Ord. No. 2006:13, § 1, 7-11-2006) 
8.04.050 - Permit and registration required. 
A.  No person shall install, connect or maintain or cause to be installed, connected or maintained any alarm system in or to the police communications center for the purpose of transmitting a signal or alarm or reporting a signal, alarm or prerecorded message to the attention of the police department for the purpose of summoning of the police department, fire department, ambulance squad or any other agency or person and obtaining some response thereto in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and the rules, regulations and procedures hereinafter established and provided thereunder. 
B.  No person shall install, connect, operate, maintain, service or own or cause to be installed, connected, operated, maintained, serviced or owned any dial alarm equipment, device or system designed to summon the police department of the Borough of Stratford, or through the police department, the fire department or other municipal agency, to any location within the Borough of Stratford in response to any type of signal, alarm, prerecorded or preprogrammed message, report or other transmission over the telephone wires without first having registered and obtained a permit therefore in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and the rules, regulations and procedures hereinafter established and provided thereunder. 
C.  No person shall install, connect or maintain or cause to be installed, connected or maintained any local alarm without first having registered the same with the chief of police as hereinafter provided. 
D.  No person shall install, connect or maintain or cause to be installed, connected or maintained any alarm system reporting to any commercial central alarm receiving station which will result in the central alarm receiving station requesting the police department, fire department or ambulance squad to respond to any location within the borough in response to signals or transmissions from the alarm system without first having registered the system with the chief of police, as hereinafter provided. 
E.  This chapter shall also apply to all persons having installed, connected and maintained any police, burglar, fire, dial, telephone, local, automatic, emergency or other alarm equipment, device or system covered or included in this chapter prior to the effective date hereof. 
F.  All existing installations and connections of police, burglar, fire, dial, telephone, automatic emergency or other alarm equipment, device or system to police communications center, shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter for the purpose of installation and connection and maintaining those alarms to the police communications center. 
(Ord. No. 98:18, (part), 1998) 
8.04.060 - Permit and registration procedures. 
A.  All applications for the issuance of a permit required under this chapter shall be made in writing to the chief of police on a form provided therefor and shall be accompanied by an application and processing fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00). 
B.  The application shall contain: The name, address and telephone number of the applicant; the name, address and telephone of each of the premises and customers or persons to be served by the proposed installation or connection; the location of the device; a description and name of alarm equipment or system; the name of the installer; the type of device, alarm equipment and system provisions relating to false alarms and testing procedures; the list of persons to be contacted in event of alarm; and such other information as may be required by the chief of police. 
C.  Upon application for a permit, the chief of police shall cause an investigation and records to be made and thereafter, provided that the applicant has complied with all the terms of this chapter and the rules and regulations made, promulgated and adopted pursuant thereto, shall issue permit. 
D.  Permit fees for present subscribers to the existing alarm system on or before the effective date of this chapter shall be waived. 
E.  Registration of local alarm systems and alarm systems connected to commercial central alarm receiving stations shall be in writing on a form provided by the chief of police. Registration of these systems shall be made before the activation of any such system. 
F.  It is the responsibility of all persons who own or occupy any land or premises in the borough at which an alarm system is installed, operating or maintained to provide to the chief of police all current information as to the names and telephone numbers of responsible persons who are to be contacted in case of emergency and who are authorized to provide service to the alarm system on a twenty-four-hour basis. This information is required to be filed with the chief of police when the alarm system is initially placed into service and must be maintained current immediately whenever any revisions or changes occur or are necessary. 
(Ord. No. 98:18, (part), 1998) 
8.04.070 - Conditions for grant of permits. 
    No permit shall be granted except upon the following terms and conditions: 
A.  The applicant shall furnish and complete all information required relating to the application and the alarm, equipment, device or system to be installed or connected and data relating to prevention of false alarms and testing procedures. 
B.  No person other than the applicant and his or her agents, family or employees shall exercise the privileges under the permit. 
C.  The applicant shall maintain his or her equipment in good condition and repair. 
D.  No permit shall be transferred or assigned in any manner. 
E.  The permit is accepted upon the express condition that the permittee shall indemnify and hold the borough harmless from and on account of any and all damages arising out of the activities of the permittee, its alarm contractor or the common annunciator licensee of the borough. 
F.  Each separate building, store, premises, place or location shall require a separate permit and a separate installation or connection to the police panel alarm system. 
G.  The applicant or permittee, upon acceptance of such permit, thereby agrees to hold and save harmless the borough, its agents or employees from any liability whatsoever in connection with any such alarm, equipment, device or system or the operation and maintenance of the same which shall be the sole responsibility of the person having had the same installed or connected. 
(Ord. No. 98:18, (part), 1998) 
8.04.080 - Revocation or suspension of permits. 
A.  Any permit issued under the provisions of this chapter may be suspended or revoked by the chief of police for any violation of, or failure to comply with, the provisions of this chapter or any rule or regulation promulgated by the chief of police and approved by borough council pursuant to this chapter, including the following: 
1.  The permittee, his or her agent or employee willfully failed to and did not comply with a request by a member of the police department to proceed immediately to the location of permittee's alarm and render necessary services. 
2.  The permittee, his or her agents or employees knowingly or carelessly installed or maintained a faulty alarm device. An inordinate number of false alarms shall be prima facie evidence that such alarm device is knowingly a faulty device. 
3.  The permittee has breached the terms and conditions of the permit. 
B.  No permit shall be revoked or suspended without giving the permittee fifteen (15) days' notice in writing of such action and within said time an opportunity to show cause before the chief of police or his or her designee why such action should not be taken. Any person aggrieved by the action or determination of the chief of police, or his or her designee, in the denial, suspension or revocation of any permit provided for in this chapter may appeal to the borough council within five (5) days of receiving such notice of the denial, suspension or revocation of the permit by filing a written notice of appeal with the borough clerk. The filing of the written notice of appeal with the borough clerk shall stay any further action by the chief of police until such appeal has been determined by the borough council. Any revocation or suspension of an alarm permit by the chief of police or his or her designee shall not prevent prosecution in municipal court for violations of any provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 98:18, (part), 1998) 
8.04.090 - Dialer alarms. 
A.  No permit shall be issued for the installation, connection, operation, maintenance, service or ownership of any type of dial alarm, equipment or device covered by the terms of this chapter unless the owner has complied with the Federal Communications Commission's regulations for such installation and connection to Bell Telephone lines and the permittee complies with the provisions of this chapter and the rules and regulations promulgated and adopted thereunder. Dialer alarms are expressly prohibited from reporting to the main police communications center phone numbers. Dialer alarms are permitted to report on only those phone lines maintained specifically for this purpose by the police department. Any dialer alarm reporting on the main police department communications telephone numbers is in violation of this chapter. 
B.  No voice dialer alarm equipment shall be connected to the police alarm system. Permits shall be issued only for installation of digital alarm transmitters to be connected to the police alarm system. 
C.  Voice dialer alarm equipment installed on or before may be continued subject to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 98:18, (part), 1998) 
8.04.100 - Local alarms. 
    All local devices, alarms, equipment or systems shall be registered with the chief of police and all information required with respect to such registration shall be provided and kept current by the applicant or registrant, and no fee shall be required therefor. All local alarms shall have a fifteen (15) minute automatic silencing or cutoff device within fifteen (15) minutes after actuation of the audible signaling device. 
(Ord. No. 98:18, (part), 1998) 
8.04.110 - Limitations and obligations. 
A.  The Borough of Stratford shall be under no duty or obligation to any permittee, or any other licensee hereunder, to maintain or continue any of the police alarm system equipment or any other equipment device or system connected thereto, the same being maintained at will and subject to termination at any time by cancellation of the system by resolution or ordinance duly adopted by the borough council. Any individual permit or license issued hereunder may be revoked at any time by the chief of police as hereinabove provided. 
B.  Notwithstanding payment of any fees and/or the receiving or issuance of any permit or registrations as herein required, the borough, chief of police, the police department and their agents and employees shall be under no obligation whatsoever concerning the installation, connection, inadequacy, operation or maintenance of any alarm, equipment, device or system installed or connected. The borough and its authorized agents assume no liability whatsoever for any failure of such alarm, equipment, device or system, any failure to respond to any such alarm or transmittals, or for any act of omission or commission as a result of any such alarm equipment device or system. The obligation for the maintenance and upkeep of such alarm equipment, device and system shall be the sole responsibility of the person having had the same installed or connected. 
(Ord. No. 98:18, (part), 1998) 
8.04.120 - Payment of charges. 
    For the equipment, device and systems installed or connected within the borough, the permittee shall pay whatever charges are required by any alarm company making such installation and, in addition thereto, the permit fee hereinabove provided and such connection, installation and annual maintenance charges licensee also hereinabove provided for in the event of installation and connection to the police alarm system. 
(Ord. No. 98:18, (part), 1998) 
8.04.130 - False alarms-Fines and disconnection. 
A.  In the case of a false alarm, any person having knowledge thereof shall immediately notify the police department in a manner to be prescribed by rules and regulations herein made and provided. In addition, in the case of a false alarm, the chief of police shall cause an investigation to be made and keep a record of said alarms on file. Where the investigation of the police department discloses continued abuse of the privilege of connection to the police alarm system or a disregard by the permittee to take remedial steps to avoid false alarms, the borough reserves the right to require disconnection from the police alarm system for a limited or permanent time upon the order of the chief of police or his or her designee, provided that no permit shall be revoked or suspended without notice and affording the permittee an opportunity to show cause before the chief of police or his or her designee why such action should not be taken, as hereinabove provided. 
B.  It shall be the responsibility of all persons who have installed, operated or maintained any alarm system within the borough to prevent the activation and/or transmission of false alarms through a program of training and periodic inspection and maintenance of the system. 
    The maximum number of permissible false alarms from any one (1) location and/or system shall be as follows: 
1.  False alarms. Any three (3) false alarms in any one (1) calendar month or eight (8) false alarms within any twelve-month period. 
2.  More than three (3) false 911 calls, activations within any twelve-month period. 
3.  False alarms in excess of the above shall be deemed a violation of this chapter, with each alarm activation being a separate citable and punishable offense. 
4.  Any alarm broadcasted from a bank, money access machine (ATM) financial institution or check cashing agency which has been deemed to be in violation of this section because of the activations are/were false, malfunctions, baseless, accidental or otherwise activated without the actual need for a response by police, fire, or EMS. Shall be for a first offense a minimum fine of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and for second and subsequent offenses, the maximum penalty allowed by ordinance, shall be applied upon conviction or a guilty finding. 
(Ord. 98:18, (part), 1998; Ord. No. 2003:03, § 1, 2-11-2003; Ord. No. 2006:13, § 2, 7-11-2006) 
8.04.140 - Unauthorized connections-Inspections. 
A.  Any unauthorized installation or connection to the police panel alarm system shall be ordered disconnected by the chief of police for noncompliance with this chapter. Any person installing, connecting or maintaining such unauthorized alarm, alarms system or equipment may be prosecuted for violation of this chapter. 
B.  Any permittee, by acceptance of a permit, shall be deemed to have consented to a reasonable inspection by the police chief or his or her designee of the lands and premises at or on which said alarm device is installed. 
(Ord. No. 98:18, (part), 1998) 
8.04.150 - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to the general alerting alarms that may be used by fire companies, ambulance squads, and civil defense agencies to summon the response of their members. The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to alarm systems that are affixed to motor vehicles, unless any such system shall be connected to or report through any alarm system installed at or affixed to a generally considered permanent structure. The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to any alarm system owned, operated or maintained by the borough. 
(Ord. No. 98:18, (part), 1998) 
8.04.160 - Rules and regulations. 
A.  The chief of police is authorized to prescribe and promulgate supplementary rules and regulations which shall adequately and sufficiently promote and ensure an effective and efficient police alarm system, and provide for the effective administration and enforcement of the provisions of this chapter. 
B.  All such rules and regulations, and revisions thereof, shall be in writing and subject to the approval of the borough council. Any rule or regulation which shall affect the permittees or licensees hereunder shall be duly promulgated and provided by the chief of police or his or her designee to such permittees or licensees. 
(Ord. No. 98:18, (part), 1998) 
8.04.170 - Penalties. 
    Any person found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this chapter by the municipal court of the borough shall be subject to a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each violation. In addition to any fine adjudicated by the court, the chief of police may suspend or revoke any alarm permit held by any permittee under the authority of section 8.04.080 of this chapter, revocation or suspension of permits, and in accordance with the rules and regulations promulgated hereunder, and cause any alarms for which said permit is revoked to be disconnected from the police alarm system. 
(Ord. No. 98:18, (part), 1998) 
Chapter 8.08 - AUTOMATIC FIRE WARNING SYSTEMS 
Sections: 

8.08.010 - Systems required in residential structures. 
    Every building or structure not exceeding thirty-five (35) feet in height above the mean grade and every building or structure containing at least one (1) dwelling unit shall be protected with an automatic fire warning system equipped with automatic smoke and gas detection devices primarily intended for the protection of life by indicating abnormal conditions as hereinafter provided. Placement of the aforesaid systems shall be in the area or areas as suggested in Section 74-13 et seq. of the below cited fire code standards. At least one (1) smoke detector shall be placed upon each level of the building. Said smoke detector shall be capable of sensing visible and invisible particles of combustion and installed in a manner and location approved by the Stratford Fire Official or his or her designee. When actuated, the detector shall provide an alarm suitable to warn the occupants within the individual dwelling unit. 
(Prior code § 62-5) 
8.08.020 - Compliance with standards required. 
    The aforesaid systems shall conform to the requirements of the current edition of National Fire Code Standard No. 74 relative to household fire warning equipment, adopted by the National Fire Protection Association. Said devices must meet with the approval of Underwriters' Laboratories, Inc., or Factory Mutual Research Corporation. 
(Prior code § 62-6) 
8.08.030 - Tests and inspections. 
    Automatic detection devices should be tested periodically as specified by the Life Safety Code, National Fire Protection Association No. 101, and Household Fire Warning Equipment, National Fire Protection Association No. 74, as periodically revised. As relates to the multifamily units, all detection devices shall be periodically inspected by the fire marshal during reasonable hours and promulgated by said fire marshal or marshals. 
(Prior code § 62-7) 
8.08.040 - Systems required in multifamily buildings. 
A.  For all multifamily buildings more than thirty-five (35) feet in height, the automatic fire warning system shall be installed as described above, and such system shall also initiate the sounding of an audible alarm capable of being heard in all occupied areas of the building or structure and shall register the location of the alarm at a specified location within the building. The sounding of this alarm shall also be tied into fire headquarters for receipt of fire alarms. 
B.  As concerns all new construction of multifamily units, applicants for building permits shall include in their construction plans the type, number and location of all detection devices. The fire marshal shall review plans and may recommend modifications as per standards set forth in the latest revisions of the Life Safety Code, National Fire Protection Association No. 101, and Household Fire Warning Equipment, National Fire Protection Association No. 74. 
(Prior code § 62-8) 
8.08.050 - Applicability. 
    This chapter shall apply to all structures requiring certificates of occupancy and constructed, under construction or altered after the effective date hereon and shall apply to all structures hereafter sold, transferred or in which there has been a change of occupants. 
(Prior code § 62-9) 
8.08.060 - Number and placement of detectors. 
    The number and placement of detectors shall be under the direct control and enforcement of the fire marshal and the bureau of fire prevention of the borough. Standards for the aforementioned parties are set forth in the latest revisions of the National Fire Code 74-12, No. 4 of Table 2-4, 3. 
(Prior code § 62-10) 
8.08.070 - Responsibility for installation of devices and inspections-Fees-Violations and penalties. 
A.  The transferor of any structure in the borough is responsible for installation of devices as set forth in section 8.08.010 of this chapter. Failure to install necessary devices shall be punishable by a fine of up to five hundred dollars ($500.00) per day for each day of violation and/or ninety (90) days in jail for each day of violation. 
B.  It shall be the duty of every owner of premises to inspect the fire warning system on a quarterly basis and, if the system is battery operated, to replace the same on a yearly basis with new, unused batteries of the proper type and size as specified by the manufacturer of the system. 
C.  Prior to the sale of any premises within the borough, it shall be inspected for compliance by the Stratford Fire Official or his or her designee for compliance with this chapter, whereupon a certificate of compliance will be issued. The fee for this inspection shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00). When any violations are noted during any inspection made pursuant to this article or under the New Jersey Uniform Fire Code, and if the reinspection is necessary, the building owner or occupant will be charged an additional fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per reinspection, except for the first reinspection, for which there will be no fee. 
(Prior code § 62-11) 
8.08.080 - Construal of provisions. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall apply without regard to the regulations of lenders or funding agencies and shall be in addition to any control exercised by such agencies concerning construction and fire protection requirements relating to such construction. 
(Prior code § 62-12) 
8.08.090 - New construction. 
    A Class A fire system and approved combination fire alarm system, as defined in National Fire Codes Nos. 13, 72, A, B, C, D and E (whichever is applicable) of the National Fire Protection Association, shall be installed in all new construction more than four (4) stories in height in the borough, specifically including tenement houses, hotels, dormitories, clubhouses, public or private houses, sanitariums, surgical institutions, asylums, hospitals or homes for the aged. 
(Prior code § 62-13) 
8.08.100 - Contractor/supplier to provide certain information. 
    Every such installing contractor/supplier of devices set forth in section 8.08.010 of this chapter shall supply to the person or persons which shall occupy such structure: 
A.  An instruction booklet illustrating typical installation layouts. 
B.  Instruction charts describing the operation, testing and proper maintenance of the system. 
C.  Printed information for establishing a household emergency evacuation plan. 
D.  Printed information to inform the owner where he may obtain repair or replacement service and where and how parts may be obtained. 
(Prior code § 62-13.1) 
Chapter 8.10 - KNOX BOX RAPID ENTRY SYSTEM 
Sections: 

8.10.010 - Purpose. 
    The purposeof this chapter is to require the installation of a Knox Box "Rapid Entry System" on new construction structures as noted below, and to establish installation requirements and compliance as determined by the Stratford Fire Chief and Stratford Code Official. 
    Experience has shown when fires occur in buildings, the fire department must make entry into the structure, locate, confine, control and extinguishment the fire. Further, fires within buildings are not always readily evident from the outside when the fire department arrives. Delaying fire department entry into a building can and will allow a fire to grow and make the fire more dangerous. When evidence of a fire is noted from the outside, forcible entry into a building is time consuming and represents a delay in locating and extinguishing the fire. In order to expedite entry into a structure and to aid the fire department in the task of extinguishment, the installation of a Knox Box "Rapid Entry System" shall be required on new construction structures and highly recommended on existing businesses as noted below. 
(Ord. No. 2018:13, § 1, 12-11-2018) 
8.10.020 - Definitions. 
    Automatic dialer: A device that automatically dials and/or relays a prerecorded message to a central station or the fire department. 
    Automatic fire supression system: A system or assembly of piping, valves, controls and sprinklers which are designed and installed to comply with the NFPA standards, which utilized water, foam, CO 2 or other as to automatically react to suppress fire. 
    Central station: An office of a private company which remote alarm and supervisory signaling devices are transmitted and where personnel are in attendance at all times to supervise the circuits and investigate signals. 
    Fire alarm system: Equipment which automatically actuates a fire decrease in temperature or activation or a sprinkler system or manually activated device. 
    Lock box: A high security key vault which is under the UL 1610 and the UL 1037 standards, master keyed with a Medeco Biaxial Level 7 or equivalent lock. Locks shall be keyed to the key configuration provided by the fire department. 
(Ord. No. 2018:13, § 2, 12-11-2018) 
8.10.030 - Requirement. 
A.  The owner or person in control of the following types of buildings shall install and maintain a rapid entry key box of a type approved by the Stratford Fire Chief and Stratford Code Official prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy: 
1.  All newly constructed buildings within the borough, having automatic alarm system, dialer, central station or equipped with an automatic fire suppression system except one and two family owner-occupied dwellings. 
2.  New constructed multi-family residential structures, including senior citizen apartment/condo complexes that have restricted access through locked doors and have a common corridor for access to the living units. 
3.  New constructed commercial and industrial buildings identified by the fire chief as difficult to access during emergencies. 
4.  All new constructed high rise buildings, i.e. structures having floors at or above fifty (50) feet above ground level. 
B.  The owner or occupant of any existing business or structure who decides to install a rapid entry key box shall be required to comply with the terms of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2018:13, § 3, 12-11-2018) 
8.10.040 - Exemptions. 
    The following structures are exempt from the mandate to install the Rapid Entry Knox Box System: 
1.  Single family structures and multi-family structures that do not meet the requirements set forth in Section 8.10.030 above. 
2.  Structures that are staffed twenty-four (24) hours a day, three hundred sixty-five (365) days a year (which may include but are not limited to nursing homes, hospitals, police stations, fire stations etc.) 
3.  Structures that have 24-hour, 365-day on site security staff or personnel on site. 
4.  Schools whether public or private. 
(Ord. No. 2018:13, § 4, 12-11-2018) 
8.10.050 - Key box location. 
A.  The key box, shall be of a UL type, and approved by the Stratford Fire Chief and Stratford Code Official. The key box shall be installed, at or near the recognized public entrance, adjacent to the fire alarm panel, on the exterior of the structure or in a location or locations designated and approved by the fire chief. 
B.  The box shall be located at a height approved by the Stratford Fire Chief and Stratford Code Official of not less than four (4) feet and not more than ten (10) feet above the final grade. The key box is not required to be attached to or monitored by the alarm system, however, this action is recommended. The Knox Box does come equipped with the option to connect to the alarm monitoring system. 
(Ord. No. 2018:13, § 5, 12-11-2018) 
8.10.060. - Knox Box contents. 
    Any Knox Box installed pursuant to this chapter shall contain the following: 
1.  Keys/fobs to locked points of access/egress, whether interior or exterior of such buildings. 
2.  Keys/fobs to all locked rooms and/or panels, including but not limited to mechanical, electrical, sprinkler and alarms. 
3.  Keys to locked elevator rooms and elevator controls. 
4.  Keys/fobs to any fenced or otherwise physically secured area. 
5.  Keys/fobs to any other areas, as determined necessary and appropriate, by the fire chief. 
6.  Emergency information card, containing the name(s) and telephone number(s) of emergency contacts for such buildings. 
(Ord. No. 2018:13, § 6, 12-11-2018) 
8.10.070 - Compliance. 
    The fire sub-code official shall be responsible for compliance with the section requirements, for all buildings currently under plan review for future construction. 
    The property owner shall immediately notify the fire chief or his designee and provide the new key(s) when a lock is changed or rekeyed. The updated key shall then be secured in the Knox Box. 
(Ord. No. 2018:13, § 7, 12-11-2018) 
8.10.080 - Penalties. 
    Penalties for non-compliance by any building owner, in violation of the provisions of this chapter, shall be subject to a penalty being assessed after receiving notice by the Stratford Fire Chief and Stratford Code Official. 
(Ord. No. 2018:13, § 8, 12-11-2018) 
Chapter 8.12 - CIGARETTES AND TOBACCO PRODUCTS 
Sections: 

8.12.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
A.  "Person" means an individual, partnership, corporation, cooperative, association or any other legal entity. 
B.  "Vending machine" means any mechanical device that displays cigarettes or tobacco products from which the consumer may purchase one of the tobacco products by the insertion of currency or a credit card, unless the vending machine has a lockout device that prevents all sales prior to scrutiny and approval of the customer by an authorized sales person. 
C.  "Self-service racks" means any display promotion of any tobacco product within a retail establishment wherein the rack or display is not specifically behind a sales counter and is within the grasp of the public so as to be self-service. 
(Prior code § 49-1; Ord. No. 97:11, § 2 (part), 1997) 
8.12.020 - Prohibition of vending machines and self-service racks. 
    All self-service racks and vending machines without lockout devices are prohibited within the borough in any retail establishment. It is unlawful for any person to possess a tobacco vending machine, without a lockout device, or to display self-service racks. 
(Prior code § 49-2; Ord. No. 97:11, § 2 (part), 1997) 
8.12.030 - Sales to minors. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to sell or permit to be sold or offered to sell any tobacco products to any individual without first requesting and examining identification from the purchaser positively establishing the purchaser's age as eighteen (18) years of age or older. It is unlawful to sell or permit to be sold any tobacco product to any person under eighteen (18) years of age. Whenever a police officer or any citizen believes that there exists a violation of this chapter, she or he may file a complaint, in juvenile or municipal court, within thirty (30) days after discovery of the alleged violation. 
B.  It is unlawful for any person to purchase tobacco products with funds furnished by a minor or with the intent to sell or give such a product to a minor. 
C.  It is unlawful for any person under eighteen (18) years of age to smoke or use tobacco products in any public place, or to possess in open view a cigarette or tobacco product, an open cigarette pack, opened carton or other opened container (as evidenced by a broken seal) holding a tobacco product. 
D.  It is unlawful for a parent, legal guardian or other persons acting in place of a parent or legal guardian or person who is responsible for the care and welfare of a minor under the age of eighteen (18) years to allow that minor to possess any cigarettes made of tobacco or any other substances which can be smoked, any cigarette paper or tobacco in any form, including but not limited to smokeless tobacco. 
(Prior code § 49-3; Ord. No. 97:11, § 2 (part), 1997; Ord. No. 98:25, § 1 (part), 1998) 
8.12.040 - Penalties. 
A.  Any person convicted of violating any provision of this chapter shall be subject to a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each offense. 
B.  Unless otherwise provided by law, a minor charged under this section as a first offense with the use or purchase of a tobacco product shall be served with a written warning which shall inform the minor of subsequent penalties. A copy of said warning shall be sent to minor's parents. 
C.  Repeat minor offenders who are found guilty of violating section 8.12.030, upon conviction thereof, shall pay a penalty of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense, as well as in addition to the penalties provided the convicted can be subject to a period of community service in accordance with the policies and procedures of juvenile administration by the Camden County Juvenile Court and the borough police department. 
(Prior code § 49-4; Ord. No. 97:11, § 2 (part), 1997; Ord. No. 98:25, § 1 (part), 1998) 
Chapter 8.16 - FIRE PREVENTION CODE ADOPTED 
Sections: 

8.16.010 - Adoption of standards by reference. 
    A certain document, of which will be on file in the Office of the Borough Clerk of the Borough of Stratford, County of Camden, being marked and designated as "International Residential and Building Codes, NJ Edition", latest published edition as adopted as the Fire Prevention Code of the Borough of Stratford in the State of New Jersey for the control of buildings and structures as herein provided; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of this edition are referred to, adopted and made part thereof, as if fully set out in this chapter. 
(Prior code § 62-1; Ord. No. 2011:02, § 01, 3-8-2011) 
8.16.020 - Permit fees. 
    The fee for any permit required under the International Residential and Building Codes, NJ Edition shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00), said sum to be paid to the borough clerk. In the case of any nonprofit corporation, application shall be made; however, no fee shall be charged. 
(Prior code § 62-3; Ord. No. 2011:02, § 02, 3-8-2011) 
8.16.030 - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person, entity, firm, corporation or other group that is found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), and each incident shall be considered a separate violation. 
(Prior code § 62-4) 
Chapter 8.20 - BUREAU OF FIRE SAFETY[1] 
Sections: 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2002:07, §§ 1-11, adopted May 14, 2002, repealed the former ch. 8.20, §§ 8.20.010-8.20.080, and enacted a new ch. 8.20 as set out herein. The former ch. 8.20, entitled "State Fire Code enforcement", pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Prior code, §§ 62-14-62-21; and Ord. No. 2002:02, adopted Jan. 8, 2002. 

8.20.010 - Local enforcement. 
    Pursuant to Section 11 of the Uniform Fire Safety Act (P.L. 1983 c. 383), the New Jersey Uniform Fire Act Code (N.J.A.C. 5:70-1 et.seq.) shall be locally enforce in the Borough of Stratford. 
(Ord. No. 2002:07, § 1, 5-14-2002; Ord. No. 2002:16, §§ 1, 2, 9-10-2002) 
8.20.020 - Agency designation. 
    The local enforcing agency shall be the bureau of fire safety, a municipal agency which is hereby created therein. The bureau of safety shall hereinafter be known as the local enforcing agency. 
(Ord. No. 2002:07, § 2, 5-14-2002; Ord. No. 2002:16, §§ 1, 2, 9-10-2002) 
8.20.030 - Duties. 
A.  The local enforcing agency shall enforce the Uniform Fire Code in all buildings, structures and premises within the established boundaries of the Borough of Stratford other than one (1) and two (2) unit owner occupied dwellings used exclusively for dwelling purposes and buildings, structures and premises owned or operated by federal government, interstate agencies or the state. 
B.  The local enforcing agency shall faithfully comply with all the pertinent requirements of the Uniform Fire Safety Act and the Uniform Fire Code. 
(Ord. No. 2002:07, § 3, 5-14-2002; Ord. No. 2002:16, §§ 1, 2, 9-10-2002) 
8.20.040 - Organizations. 
A.  The bureau of fire safety established by section 8.20.020 of this chapter shall be under the direct supervision and control of a fire official who shall report to the mayor and council. 
B.  The bureau of fire safety shall have at least one (1) paid inspector. 
(Ord. No. 2002:07, § 4, 5-14-2002; Ord. No. 2002:16, §§ 1, 2, 9-10-2002) 
8.20.050 - Appointments, qualifications, terms of office, removal. 
A.  Appointment and qualifications of the fire official. The fire official shall be certified by the state and appointed by the governing body per the department of personnel guidelines set forth in Title 4A. 
B.  Appointment and qualifications of inspectors and other employees. Inspectors and other employees of the enforcing agency shall be appointed by the governing body upon recommendations of the fire official. All life hazard use inspectors shall be certified by the state. 
C.  Appointment of legal counsel. The governing body shall specifically appoint legal counsel to assist the agency in enforcing the Uniform Fire Code. 
D.  Term of office. The fire official shall serve for a term of a minimum of one (1) year. Any vacancy shall serve for a minimum of one (1) year. Any vacancy shall be filled for the unexpired term. 
E.  Removal from office. The fire official, inspectors and other employees of the agency shall be subject to removal by the governing body for just cause. Before removal from office, all persons shall be afforded an opportunity to be heard by the governing body or a hearing officer designated by the same. 
(Ord. No. 2002:07, § 5, 5-14-2002; Ord. No. 2002:16, §§ 1, 2, 9-10-2002) 
8.20.060 - Life hazards. 
    The bureau of fire safety established by section 8.20.020 of this chapter shall carry out the periodic inspections of life hazard uses required by the Uniform Fire Code on behalf of the Commissioner of the New Jersey Department of Community Affairs. 
(Ord. No. 2002:07, § 6, 5-14-2002; Ord. No. 2002:16, §§ 1, 2, 9-10-2002) 
8.20.070 - Nonlife hazard uses. 
    In addition to the registrations required by the Uniform Fire Code, nonlife hazard uses shall register with the bureau of fire safety. These uses shall be inspected once per year and pay an annual fee. The fee is not to be used for life hazard uses as defined in the Uniform Fire Code. 
(Ord. No. 2002:07, § 7, 5-14-2002; Ord. No. 2002:16, §§ 1, 2, 9-10-2002) 
8.20.080 - Permit and certificate of fire code status. 
A.  Permit fees. In accordance with the current rules and regulations of the New Jersey Department of Community Affairs N.J.A.C. 5:70-2.8(c).
