For the purposes of this chapter, any vehicle containing advertising matter intending to promote the interest of any business, or any vehicle used in connection with the business whether or not said vehicle is registered as a commercial vehicle with the New Jersey State Division of Motor Vehicles is considered a commercial vehicle. 
    "Front yard", for the purpose of this chapter, is defined as follows: An open unoccupied space on the same lot with a building situated between the nearest roofed portion of the building and the street line of the lot and extending from side lot line to side lot line. It is not intended to include all or any part of a paved driveway leading either to a legal parking area at the side or rear of lot or to an attached or detached garage. 
    "Recreational vehicles", for the purpose of this chapter, includes the following: 
1.  Boat. A watercraft propelled by oars, paddles, sail or power. 
2.  Camper-trailer. A vehicular, portable dwelling structure designed to be used for recreational purposes. This includes a travel trailer, so identified by the manufacturer; a pickup camper; a folding tent trailer; and a motorized camper where the camping portion is an integral part of the self-propelled vehicle. 
3.  Motor home. A self-contained vehicle designed for human habitation with its own motive power and with a passage from the body of the homes to the driver's and front passenger's seat. 
4.  Trailer. A vehicle without motive power designed for carrying persons or property on its own and to be drawn by a vehicle with motive power. The term "trailer" shall include, but shall not be limited to, horse trailers, boat trailers and skimobile trailers. 
    "Storage", within the meaning of this provision shall refer to placement for more than seven (7) days. Temporary parking of recreational vehicles shall be permitted in residential zones upon application to the police department for a temporary parking permit which may be issued for a period not to exceed seven (7) days. Active loading or unloading of recreational vehicles shall not constitute temporary parking and is permitted with a temporary parking permit in residential zones. 
(Prior code § 102-6a; Ord. No. 2007:05, § 1, 3-13-2007) 
10.16.020 - Prohibited parking. 
A.  The parking of automobiles, buses, motorcycles, trailers and other vehicles in the front yard of lots within the borough is prohibited at all times. 
B.  Parking of automobiles, buses, limousines, trucks and similar vehicles are prohibited from parking on any grassed area or nonpaved area of the property. 
C.  Automobiles, buses, limousines, trucks and similar vehicles are prohibited from being parked in the rear of the home unless it is a paved driveway. 
(Ord. No. 2007:19, § 2, 10-9-2007) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2007:19, § 1, adopted Oct. 9, 2007, deleted the former § 10.16.020 and enacted a new § 10.16.020 as set out herein. The former § 10.16.020 was entitled "parking in front yards prohibited" pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Prior code § 102-6b. 
10.16.030 - Overnight parking of commercial vehicles prohibited. 
    No person, firm or corporation who owns or operates a commercial vehicle, excluding emergency vehicles, shall park or let stand said vehicle on any public roadway or street in the borough between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. The fact that any such vehicle specifically precluded is disabled shall not be grounds for relentment of the effect of this section, and any such vehicle so disabled shall be promptly removed by the owner or operator so as not to constitute a violation as herein set forth. 
(Prior code § 102-6c) 
10.16.040 - Commercial vehicle exception to overnight parking. 
    One (1) commercial vehicle of a rated capacity not exceeding one-ton weight and/or four (4) wheels, owned and operated by a resident on the premises, shall be permitted to be regularly parked or garaged on a residential property including the public street, provided that said vehicle is not parked in a front yard. 
    School buses under sixteen (16) feet in length are limited to one (1) per residential property. The school bus must be parked in the driveway to the furthest point in said driveway from the driveway apron. 
(Prior code § 102-6d; Ord. No. 97:5, (part), 1997; Ord. No. 98:24, § 1, 1998:1) 
10.16.050 - Parking of recreational vehicles prohibited. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall park a recreational vehicle upon any roadway or street within the borough. 
(Prior code § 102-6e) 
10.16.060 - Storage of recreational vehicles. 
    The outdoor storage of recreational vehicles is permitted only upon the following conditions: 
A.  Such storage shall not be located in any front yard. 
B.  Only one (1) such trailer, small boat or camper-trailer shall be permitted to be stored. 
C.  Any such vehicle stored in accordance with this section shall not be occupied and shall not be provided with utility connections other than for the maintenance of such vehicle. 
D.  Any trailer, small boat or camper-trailer or stored in side or rear yard shall meet the applicable zoning district regulations governing setbacks for accessory buildings from property lines and buildings. 
(Prior code § 102-6f; Ord. No. 2006:07, § 1, 5-9-2006; Ord. No. 2007:05, § 2, 3-13-2007) 
10.16.065 - Prohibited in residential zones. 
A.  Boats in excess of twenty-one (21) feet or more in length as measured from outside dimensions, including hitching devices, unless they are stored within an enclosed building at all times. 
1.  Motor homes with a height of ten (10) feet or more, and a length equal or greater than twenty-eight (28) feet, unless they are stored within an enclosed building at all times. 
2.  (Any resident who can show proof they owned a motor home at the time the ordinance from which this section derives is adopted will be given pre-existing approval, and will also be given permission to replace their motor home with another one as long as it is replaced within thirty (30) days of selling their pre-existing motor home.) 
3.  Flatbed tow truck or wrecker (also known as a rollback or slide) defined as the entire back of the truck is fitted with a bed that can be hydraulically inclined and moved to ground level, allowing the vehicle being towed to be placed on it under its own power or pulled by a winch. 
4.  Flatbed or platform truck defined as a level bed body with no sides or roof. 
5.  Stakebody truck defined as a flat truck body having sockets into which stakes may be fitted, as to support railings. 
B.  In R-2 single-family attached residential district and/or R-3 multifamily residential district: 
1.  The outdoor storage of recreational vehicles as defined by section 10.16.010. 
2.  The parking of any type of vehicle on any section of the property other than the legal paved driveway or parking area in the front of the dwelling, or the attached or detached garage. 
(Ord. No. 2007:05, § 2, 3-13-2007; Ord. No. 2011:07, § 01, 8-9-2011) 
10.16.070 - Violations-Penalties. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Prior code § 102-6g) 
10.16.080 - Parking of tractor-trailer prohibited. 
    No person, firm, association, corporation or operator of a tractor-trailer shall park or let stand any tractor-trailer as defined in N.J.S.A. 30:1-1 on any public roadway, street or parking lot other than to let stand for loading or unloading at any time. 
(Prior code § 102-6.1) 
Chapter 10.20 - PARKING IN SHOPPING CENTERS AND OTHER DESIGNATED AREAS 
Sections: 

10.20.010 - Definitions. 
    Whenever any words and phrases are used in this chapter, the meanings respectively ascribed to them in N.J.R.S. Subtitle I of Title 39 shall be deemed to apply to such words and phrases used herein. 
(Prior code § 83-1) 
10.20.020 - Regulations not exclusive. 
    The provisions of this chapter imposing restrictive parking shall not relieve any person of the duty to observe other and more restrictive provisions prohibiting the parking of vehicles as set forth in N.J.S.A. 39:4-138 or any other New Jersey Statute or as hereinafter provided. 
(Prior code § 83-2) 
10.20.030 - Parking prohibited in certain areas. 
A.  No person shall park or stop with a vehicle at any time upon any of the following areas or parts thereof as set forth below: 
1.  The shopping center at Warwick Road and Longwood Drive, also known as Block 116, Lot 14, in the area from the curbline in front of the stores to a distance of forty (40) feet to the edge of the marked parking area. 
2.  The shopping center located on the White Horse Pike at Block 62, Lot 2, in the area from the curbline in front of the anchor store closest to the White Horse Pike to a distance of thirty-three (33) feet to the edge of the marked parking area. 
3.  The shopping center located on the White Horse Pike at Block 62, Lot 2, from the curbline in front of the small stores between the anchor stores for a distance of thirty-one and five-tenths (31.5) feet to the edge of the marked parking area. 
4.  The shopping center located on the White Horse Pike at Block 62, Lot 2, from the curbline in front of the anchor store farthest from the White Horse Pike to a distance of thirty (30) feet to the edge of the marked parking area. 
5.  Any portion of Block 114, Lots 30 through 111, inclusive, or upon any street adjacent to said lots, except and unless the person has obtained, from the duly designated homeowners' association for said premises, temporary or permanent identification cards or stickers, which shall be placed within or upon said person's vehicle and shall adequately identify the vehicle of said person as authorized to be parked or stopped upon said premises and/or street. 
B.  The areas extending a distance of ten (10) feet from the curblines in front of the stores at Block 116, Lot 14, and at Block 62, Lot 2, are designated as fire zones. Markings shall be painted on the ground and curb in said areas, at each location, indicating these areas as being fire zones, signs shall also be posted and shall state "No Parking - Fire Zone". [See Attachment A, for designated list, attached to Ordinance No. 2006:15 on file.] 
C.  Arrows shall be drawn on the driveways at Block 116, Lot 14, and at Block 62. Lot 2, designating in-and-out traffic. 
(Prior code § 83-3; Ord. No. 2006:15, § 1, 7-11-2006) 
10.20.040 - Signs. 
    Appropriate signs shall be installed designating the areas so regulated. All such signs shall conform to the current statutes and Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways of the State of New Jersey. 
(Prior code § 83-4) 
10.20.050 - Violations and penalties-Enforcement. 
A.  Unless another penalty is expressly provided by New Jersey Statute, every person convicted of a violation of a provision of this chapter or any supplement thereto shall be liable to a penalty of not more than fifty dollars ($50.00) or imprisonment for a term not exceeding fifteen (15) days, or both. 
B.  This chapter shall be administered and enforced by the Police Department of the Borough of Stratford. 
(Prior code § 83-5) 
10.20.060 - Title. 
    This chapter may be known and cited as the "no parking traffic ordinance". 
(Prior code § 83-6) 
Chapter 10.24 - PARKING AREA MAINTENANCE 
Sections: 

10.24.010 - Purpose. 
    The Borough Council of the Borough of Stratford, believing that certain action is reasonably required to preserve and safeguard the public health, safety, welfare and morals, and being desirous of providing for the cleanliness, maintenance and preservation of parking areas and other areas provided for or acquired in connection with any subject premises, does enact this chapter regulating the use and maintenance of parking areas, accessory areas or other open space used in connection therewith. 
(Prior code § 82-1) 
10.24.020 - Definitions. 
    The following terms, when used herein, shall have the following meanings: 
    "Accessory areas" means any buffer zones, setbacks, side and rear yards or other areas, whether surfaced or natural, or any open space used in connection with the subject premises. 
    "Garbage" means any material, goods, wares, merchandise, ingredients, parts or byproducts thereof which are sold, offered for sale, manufactured, processed, repaired or assembled by business or commercial firms or private individuals which have been discarded and contained waste matter from any animal, fish, fowl, fruit or vegetable matter resulting from said use, storage and growth of food, garden and tree fruits and vegetables, yard trimmings (properly packed grass, small tree branches, cuttings from shrubs, brush or hedges and leaves), tin, glass or other food containers, discarded combustible and noncombustible waste materials, soil, ashes, residue from combustible materials, newspapers, paper, rags, cartons, boxes, excelsior, straw, rubber, leather, metals, mineral matter, crockery, dust and sweepings from buildings. 
    "Garbage container" means a covered container which is rodent-, varmint- and insect-proof. 
    "Invitee" means any employee, visitor, customer or any other person upon a subject premises, whether invited or not, directly or indirectly. 
    "Parking area" means space provided for the parking of a vehicle, together with the means of ingress and egress thereto and the roads and driveways of any subject premises. 
    "Subject premises" means any premises which contain, in whole or in part, any parking area servicing any industrial, commercial, professional, educational or entertainment with a recreational use; or any premises which contain, in whole or in part, any parking area in conjunction with apartments or other multiple-dwelling units; or any premises which contain, in whole or in part, any parking area servicing any area regularly used for purposes or functions to which the general public is invited, directly or indirectly; the ingress and egress thereto; roads and driveways therein; buffer zones; setbacks or other open space in connection with any of the above-described uses; or any other open areas provided for in connection with the issuance of a certificate of occupancy, variance or special permit is required pursuant to the Zoning Code of the Borough of Stratford or any law applicable to such premises or use thereof. 
    "Trash container" means a container with a swing cover to receive hand-carried discarded paper and trash. 
    "User" means any owner, tenant, trustee, receiver, executor, administrator or other person who controls, in whole or in part, any subject premises. 
(Prior code § 82-2) 
10.24.030 - Certain acts prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any user of a subject premises to fail to comply with the following: 
A.  Keep same free and clear of dirt, debris, rubbish, garbage and other obstructions and to keep the same properly repaired and maintained. 
B.  Keep all roads, driveways and means of ingress and egress free of snow and ice. 
C.  Keep parking areas sufficiently clear of snow as to permit proper use of the parking area. 
D.  Keep all water drains and water drainage systems for said parking area driveways and roads therein clean and in good working order. 
E.  Provide sufficient off-street parking spaces. In determining whether sufficient parking spaces have been provided, consideration shall be given to the necessity of providing additional areas for passageways, driveways and turning which shall be furnished and trees which may be necessary. All such spaces shall be deemed to be required spaces on the lot on which they are situated and shall not be encroached upon or reduced in any manner. All parking spaces with additional passageways, driveways and turning areas, except when provided in connection with one-family residences, shall be surfaced with a dustless, durable, all-weather pavement parking surface as approved by the planning board and as recommended by the borough engineer, and shall be clearly marked for car spaces. 
F.  Keep all prescribed lights in good working condition and lighted as required by law. All parking areas and appurtenant passageways and driveways serving the subject premises shall be illuminated adequately during the hours between sunset and sunrise. After 10:00 p.m., throughout the entire lot forty (40) percent of the lights in the parking area of the subject premises shall remain lighted until sunrise. Adequate shielding shall be provided by users of the subject premises to protect adjacent residential zones from the glare of illumination and from that of automobile headlights. 
G.  Keep all sidewalks, fences, buffer zones, side and rear yards and setbacks clean and the grass, shrubbery, retaining walls, slopes and other space in connection therewith in a well-maintained order. All curbings, fences, screening or signs shall also be properly maintained. 
H.  Keep the parking lines for parking spaces required properly painted and marked. 
I.  Keep all exterior areas free and clear of the storage of goods, wares and merchandise except for reasonable periods for loading and unloading. 
J.  Keep all garbage stored in the designated place or places and in proper garbage receptacles. 
K.  Keep placed at convenient locations proper trash receptacles which shall be sufficiently serviced to prevent an overflow. 
L.  Install parking bumpers and keep same in good condition in such a position that same shall separate sidewalks or any pedestrian walkway from parking areas. 
(Prior code § 82-3) 
10.24.040 - Enforcement-Notice of violation-Action by borough. 
A.  This chapter shall be administered and enforced by the building inspector or site plan enforcement officer of the borough. 
B.  Upon determination by the building inspector or site plan enforcement officer that a violation of section 10.24.030 of this chapter exists, he or she shall serve upon the user of the subject premises a written notice of said violation and shall mail a copy of said notice to the owner of record of said subject premises at the address shown on the last preceding assessment role. If said violation is not corrected within ten (10) days of the issuance of said notice, the building inspector or site plan enforcement officer is authorized, empowered and permitted to apply for relief before any court of competent jurisdiction by the filing of a complaint alleging the violation hereof. 
C.  In addition to any penalty provided for in this chapter or any other ordinance of the borough, whenever any government agency of the borough requires screening facilities for any subject premises, the building inspector or site plan enforcement officer, upon the direction of the borough council, is authorized and empowered to erect, replace, repair or maintain fences, trees, plantings, shrubbery or other screening on land within the borough if, after thirty (30) days have expired since the issuance of letters by registered mail addressed to the owner of record of such premises as shown on the last preceding assessment role, such fences, trees, plantings, shrubbery or other screening are not so erected, replaced, repaired or maintained by or on behalf of such owner. All costs and expenses incurred by the borough in connection with any said action hereinabove described shall be assessed against the land on which such screening facilities are located. Any time a notice is sent pursuant to the provisions of this section, a copy of this section shall be attached to said notice. 
(Prior code § 82-4; Ord. No. 2007:25, §§ 1, 2, 12-27-2007) 
10.24.050 - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment in the county jail for a period not to exceed ninety (90) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment; and each violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, and each day the same is violated, shall be deemed and taken to be a separate and distinct offense. 
(Prior code § 82-5) 
10.24.060 - Interpretation of provisions-Repealer. 
    This chapter shall not act as a limitation upon any other ordinance, law, rule, regulation or certificate which may affect any premises subject to this chapter or any penalty, fine or liability thereunder, but is in addition thereto. Any ordinance, regulation, order, certificate or part thereof which is inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter is, to the extent of such inconsistency, repealed. 
(Prior code § 82-6) 
Chapter 10.28 - TRAFFIC CONTROLS FOR STREET AND HIGHWAY CONSTRUCTION AND MAINTENANCE OPERATIONS 
Sections: 

10.28.010 - Adoption of Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways. 
    Mayor and council finds and declares that problems of traffic control occur when traffic must be moved through or around street construction, maintenance operations, and utility work, above and below ground which requires blocking the roadway and obstructing the normal flow of traffic; and that such obstructions are or can become dangerous when not properly controlled. In order to better promote the public health, safety, peace and welfare, it is necessary to establish controls and regulations directed to the safe and expeditious movement of traffic through construction and maintenance zones and to provide safety for the work force performing these operations. 
    The Borough of Stratford, in the County of Camden, State of New Jersey, does adopt the current Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices, hereafter known as M.U.T.C.D., except as supplemented and amended, as it controls and regulates whenever construction maintenance operations of utility work obstructs the normal flow of traffic. Any person, contractor, or utility who fails to comply with the provisions of M.U.T.C.D. while performing such work is in violation of this section. 
(Prior code § 102-40; Ord. No. 97:09, (part), 1997) 
10.28.020 - Pre-construction meetings. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the person, contractor, or in the case of a public utility as required under the public utility agreement, wishing to conduct work on, under or above the roadway to contact the Stratford Police Department in order to arrange a pre-construction meeting to submit plans for the safe movement of traffic during such period of construction of work. Any person, contractor or utility who fails to comply with this section prior to the start of such work or whose plans are not approved by the Stratford Police Department is in violation of this section. 
(Prior code § 102-41; Ord. No. 97:09, (part), 1997) 
10.28.030 - Hazardous conditions. 
    The person, contractor, or utility shall provide the Stratford Police Department with at least two (2) emergency contact phone numbers to be called in case of emergency problems at the construction or maintenance site prior to the start of any work. If for any reason emergency contact cannot be reached, or if the emergency contact person does not respond to the call from the police department to correct a hazardous condition, the borough may respond to correct such hazardous conditions. The reasonable fees for such emergency service by the borough shall be charged to the person, contractor, or utility responsible for such conditions. 
(Prior code § 102-42; Ord. No. 97:09, (part), 1997) 
10.28.040 - Hours. 
    There shall be no construction, maintenance operations, or utility work on any roadway in the borough before the hour of 9:00 a.m. or after 4:00 p.m. This time limit may be adjusted to permit work prior to 9:00 a.m., or after 4:00 p.m. by the officer in charge of the Stratford Police Department. If it is determined by the officer in charge that the construction or maintenance operations prior to 9:00 a.m. or after 4:00 p.m. would substantially delay traffic or cause a safety or health hazard, the work shall then be permitted only between 9:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. 
(Prior code § 102-43; Ord. No. 97:09, (part), 1997) 
10.28.050 - Road closings and detours. 
    Road closing and/or traffic detours shall not be permitted unless approved by the Stratford Police Department. 
(Prior code § 102-44; Ord. No. 97:09, (part), 1997) 
10.28.060 - Traffic directors. 
    Traffic directors shall be posted at all construction or maintenance sites when determined by the Stratford Police Department that same is necessary to provide for the safe and expeditious movement of traffic. 
(Prior code § 102-45; Ord. No. 97:09, (part), 1997) 
10.28.070 - Stop work. 
    The Stratford Police Department shall have the authority to stop work including the removal of equipment and vehicles, stored material within the street right-of-way, back filling of open excavations and/or other related work, in order to abate any nuisance and/or safety hazard or for any violation of this section. 
(Prior code § 102-46; Ord. No. 97:09, (part), 1997) 
10.28.080 - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person, contractor or utility who violates any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to any combination of the follows: 
A.  A fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00), nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
B.  A term of imprisonment not exceeding ninety (90) days. 
C.  A period of community service not exceeding ninety (90) days. 
D.  A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Prior code § 102-47; Ord. No. 97:09, (part), 1997) 
Chapter 10.30 - TRAFFIC CONTROL SIGNAL MONITORING SYSTEM 
Sections: 

10.30.010 - Installation. 
(a)  The municipality hereby determines to install and utilize a traffic control signal monitoring system [system] at various intersections within the municipality as approved by the commissioner of transportation pursuant to the act. 
(b)  The system to be installed shall be approved but the governing body by resolution. 
(c)  The municipality shall have the authority to enter into a contract, following a lawful procurement process, for the installation of the system. Any contract that shall contain provisions contrary to the act shall not be deemed invalid but rather reformed to conform to the act. 
(d)  The signs notifying drivers that a system is being utilized shall be approved by the municipal engineer, and shall be placed on each street converging into the affected intersection as required by the act. 
(e)  The municipal engineer shall inspect and certify the system at least once every six (6) months from the date of its installation. 
(Ord. No. 2009:04, § 1, 2-10-2009) 
10.30.020 - Issuance of the summons. 
    The police department of the municipality shall review the recorded images produced by the system, to determine whether sufficient evidence exists demonstrating that a traffic control signal violation has occurred and shall issue a summons when appropriate in accordance with the rules of the court. 
(Ord. No. 2009:04, § 2, 2-10-2009) 
10.30.030 - Use of recorded images. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this section, the recorded images produced by the system shall be available for the exclusive use of the police department for the purpose of discharging his or her duties under P.L.2007, Ch. 348. 
(b)  Any recorded image or information produced in connection with the system shall not be deemed a public record in N.J.S.A 47:1A-1 et seq., or common law. The recorded images shall not be: (i) discoverable as a public record by any person, entity, or governmental agency, except upon a subpoena issued by a grand jury or a court order in a criminal matter; or (ii) offered as evidence in any civil or administrative proceeding not directly related to a traffic control signal violation. 
(c)  Any recorded image or information collected in connection with a traffic control signal violation shall not be retained after sixty (60) [days] following the collection of any fine or penalty. 
(d)  If a summons is not issued within forty (40) business days following the traffic control signal violation, all recorded images and any information collected with respect to the traffic control signal violation shall be removed by the police department within two (2) business days. 
(e)  The municipality shall certify compliance of this section by filing a report with the commissioner of transportation in accordance with the act. 
(Ord. No. 2009:04, § 3, 2-10-2009) 
10.30.040 - Owner's liability. 
    The liability of the owner and operator of a motor vehicle for a traffic control signal violation summons pursuant to the system shall be joint subject to provisions of the act. 
(Ord. No. 2009:04, § 4, 2-10-2009) 
Chapter 10.32 - OFF-ROAD VEHICLE OPERATION 
Sections: 

10.32.010 - Operation on borough-owned land prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to operate any type of licensed or unlicensed motor-driven vehicle or conveyance, including, but not necessarily limited to, snowmobiles, two-wheel motor vehicles known as mini-bicycles, trail bicycles, motor scooters and four-wheel motor vehicles, commonly known as go-carts, upon any borough-owned land in the borough. 
(Prior code § 103-1) 
10.32.020 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings indicated: 
    "Borough-owned land" means and includes all parks, recreation areas, ball parks, lake areas, storage facilities, garage areas, board of education property and any and all other borough or publicly owned land and premises. 
(Prior code § 103-2) 
10.32.030 - Operation on private property restricted. 
    The operation of any licensed or unlicensed motor-driven vehicle as defined in section 10.32.010, is additionally prohibited upon private property, where such operation creates loud, unnecessary or unusual noise so as to disturb or interfere with the peace and quiet of other persons. 
(Prior code § 103-3) 
10.32.040 - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be sentenced to a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) or to imprisonment for any term not exceeding ninety (90) days, or both. 
(Prior code § 103-4) 
Chapter 10.36 - JOHN F. KENNEDY MEMORIAL HOSPITAL TRAFFIC RULES 
Sections: 

10.36.010 - Parking along curbs. 
    No person shall park a vehicle at any time in and along the curbs abutting the sidewalks adjacent to the hospital building or building area. 
(Prior code § 102-45) 
10.36.020 - Parking within designated lanes. 
    In all other areas, vehicles shall be parked only in accordance with and within the lanes designated on the parking surface. 
(Prior code § 102-46) 
10.36.030 - Commercial and truck deliveries. 
    All commercial and truck deliveries shall be made at the receiving platform, in the food services court and at the general stores receiving platform. 
(Prior code § 102-47) 
10.36.040 - Traffic control signs. 
    All signs shall conform to the current Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways. 
(Prior code § 102-48) 
10.36.050 - One-way designations-Ingress and egress. 
    One-way designations shall be in the directions indicated on the site plan dated April 1, 1968, bearing the latest revised date of February 24, 1972, copies of which are on file with the borough clerk and the New Jersey Department of Transportation, provided that there shall be both ingress and egress to the John F. Kennedy Memorial Hospital parking lot from and to Laurel Road. The said site plan shall reflect this provision. 
(Prior code § 102-49)

Chapter 10.40 - ABANDONED AND JUNKED VEHICLES 
Sections: 

10.40.010 - Findings. 
    It is determined and declared that the abandonment or outside storage of any motor vehicles not currently in use for transportation, whether or not currently licensed or registered, on any public or private property within the borough is contrary and harmful to the public welfare in that such articles so abandoned or stored attract or may attract persons of tender years who, being so attracted, may play in and about them and be injured and in that such vehicles so abandoned or stored outside deteriorate and are unsightly and, as such, are detrimental to and depreciate the value of the property in the neighborhood and affect the entire borough and, further, that said abandoned vehicles constitute a danger to the public health and safety. 
(Prior code § 101-1) 
10.40.020 - Definitions. 
    The following terms, phrases and words, as used in and for the purpose of this chapter, shall be deemed to have the following meanings: 
    "Abandoned motor vehicle" means and includes any motor vehicle, omnibus, road tractor, trailer, truck, truck-tractor and vehicle which: 
1.  Has remained on or about private property or public property without the consent of the owner or other person so in charge of said property for a continuing period of more than ten (10) days; 
2.  Does not have current license plates or registration; 
3.  Is found to be mechanically inoperative and is allowed to remain inoperative for a period of ten (10) days; or 
4.  Is found without one (1) or more tires. 
    "Junk automobile" , "junk automobile body" or "other junk vehicle" means any vehicle which is no longer in actual use as a motor vehicle or such vehicle as is incapable of being operated safely or being put in a safe operational condition except at a cost in excess of the value thereof. 
    "Motor vehicle, omnibus, road tractor, trailer, truck, truck-tractor and vehicle". Intended to have the meanings stated and defined in N.J.S.A. 39:1-1 et seq. 
    "Person" means any individual, firm, partnership or corporation, being the owner or having any legal right in or to the motor vehicle or other vehicle as herein defined, but said term shall not include any commercial enterprise engaged in the business of towing or motor vehicle repair. 
    "Police department" means the Police Department of the Borough of Stratford. 
    "Repair" means that work performed or to be performed upon any vehicle, including, but not limited to, motors, ignition systems, transmission, drive train, electric system or body or fender work. 
(Prior code § 101-2) 
10.40.030 - Repairs-Outside storage. 
A.  No person shall authorize, permit, allow or suffer the repair, service or overhaul of any motor vehicle, of any description, upon any public parking lot, highway, street or alley within the borough except when such repairs are necessary in an immediate emergency. Emergency repairs necessary to place said vehicle in operation may be made upon said public highway, street, parking lot or alley, provided that said emergency repairs can be completed in less than sixty (60) minutes or unless an extra period of time has been granted by the person in charge of the police department at the time of the emergency. 
B.  It shall be unlawful for any person to store or permit to be stored on any property in the borough an abandoned or junk vehicle, as defined herein, out of doors upon any private lands in the borough, except as set forth in subsection C. Nothing herein contained shall be deemed to prohibit the placing, keeping or storage of any such vehicle in an enclosed garage, barn or other buildings or in accordance with any provisions of the zoning ordinance of the borough. 
C.  Any person may keep on his or her own private property for thirty (30) days a vehicle which would otherwise be classified as abandoned, provided that said vehicle is being kept for repair or sale. The property owner must immediately register such motor vehicle with the chief of police, and no more than one (1) such vehicle may be so kept on the private land. 
(Prior code § 101-3) 
10.40.040 - Report of complaints-Notice to remove-Action upon noncompliance. 
A.  Upon complaint of any resident or property owner of the borough or any employee of the borough, the chief of police or his or her designated agent shall make an investigation of the conditions complained of and report thereon, in writing, as to the conditions found. Upon receiving such report, if the property in question about which the complaint was made is found to be in violation of this chapter, the chief of police or his or her agent shall notify the owner or possessor of the property, personally or by mail, to take steps to effectively remove the violation from the property within ten (10) days after receipt of such notice. 
B.  The chief of police or his or her designated agent shall reinspect said lands after the ten-day period shall have expired, and, if it is found that a condition complained of and previously found to exist in violation of this chapter has not been abated or remedied, such member of the police department shall remove or secure the removal of such vehicle to a garage or place for the impounding. The person owning the same shall first pay the reasonable cost of removal and storage which may result from such a removal before regaining possession of the vehicle. 
(Prior code § 101-4) 
10.40.050 - Violations and penalties. 
A.  Any person who violates the provisions of this chapter shall, in addition to such other penalties as may be prescribed, pay all cost of removal and impounding, and, in the event that the violator is a property owner, said costs and such other fines and penalties as may be levied in accordance with this chapter shall become a lien upon his or her property in accordance with law and be collected in the manner ascribed and established for the collection of liens. 
B.  Any person who violates the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine not exceeding one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or by imprisonment not exceeding ninety (90) days, or both, at the discretion of the judge of the municipal court of the borough, and each day that such a violation shall continue shall be deemed a separate offense. 
C.  A continuance of a violation or a noncompliance with the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed a nuisance, and the borough council shall have the right to apply to the courts of this state for injunctive relief or other relief in addition to the penalties provided herein. 
(Prior code § 101-5)

Title 11 - SCHOOL SYSTEMS 
Chapters: 
Chapter 11.04 - ENROLLMENT 
Sections: 

11.04.010 - Nonresident enrollment. 
A.  It shall be unlawful for any person or guardian to assist, aid, abet, allow, permit, suffer or encourage a minor to register or enroll in the Stratford School System where the minor is ineligible to attend as a result of the minor's nonresident status. 
B.  It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly permit his or her name, address or other residence designating documentation to be utilized in the registration or enrollment of any nonresident student in the Borough of Stratford School System unless previously approval has been granted by the Superintendent of the Stratford School System or his or her designee. 
C.  Any person violating or failing to comply with any of the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(Ord. No. 2004:13, §§ 1-3, 4-13-2004) 
Title 12 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC PLACES 
Chapters: 
Chapter 12.04 - STREET AND SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR 
Sections: 
Article 1 - Construction Standards 

12.04.010 - Compliance with requirements. 
    All persons, firms or corporations engaging in the construction of curbs, gutters, walks, road pavements and establishing of street grades in the Borough of Stratford, Camden County, State of New Jersey, shall comply with the following specifications and minimum requirements relating thereto before said construction is begun. 
(Prior code § 93-1) 
12.04.020 - Grades. 
    Streets, roads and avenues shall be constructed to lines and grades established by the engineer of the borough or approved by him or her. The minimum grade to which any street, road or avenue shall be constructed shall be three-tenths of one (1) percent or a three-tenths-foot rise or fall in one hundred (100) feet. 
(Prior code § 93-2) 
12.04.030 - Concrete curbs. 
    Concrete curbs shall be constructed to the following described cross-sections: Top, six (6) inches in width; bottom, seven (7) inches in width; depth, eighteen (18) inches. The curb face shall be six (6) inches. Concrete curbs shall be constructed in accordance with the New Jersey State Highway Department Standard Specifications. If deemed necessary by the mayor and council of the borough, the size of curbs may be changed to the cross-section determined by it. 
(Prior code § 93-3) 
12.04.040 - Concrete gutters. 
    Concrete gutters shall be constructed to a minimum width of two (2) feet and a thickness of eight (8) inches. Concrete gutters shall be constructed in accordance with New Jersey State Highway Department Standard Specifications. If deemed necessary by the mayor and council of the borough, the size of gutters may be changed to the cross-section determined by it. 
(Prior code § 93-4) 
12.04.050 - Concrete walks. 
    Concrete walks shall be constructed to a minimum width of four (4) feet and to a thickness of four (4) inches except at driveways, where they shall be constructed to a depth of eight (8) inches. Concrete walks shall be constructed in accordance with New Jersey State Highway Department Standard Specifications. 
(Prior code § 93-5) 
12.04.060 - Pavements. 
    Road pavements shall be constructed of bituminous-treated gravel, soil cement, penetration macadam, bituminous concrete, street asphalt or reinforced Portland cement concrete. Road pavements shall be constructed in accordance with New Jersey State Highway Department Standard Specifications. Thickness of pavements, width and cross-section thereof, as well as the type of pavement to be used, shall be determined by the borough engineer and approved by the mayor and council. 
(Prior code § 93-6) 
12.04.070 - Plans and profiles. 
    Before any street, road or avenue in the borough shall be graded or paving shall be constructed, plans and profiles of the proposed grading or construction shall be submitted to the engineer of the borough for his or her consideration and recommendation to the mayor and council of the borough for their approval or disapproval. Plans shall be made to a scale of one (1) inch equals fifty (50) feet. Profiles shall be made to a scale of one (1) inch equals five (5) feet vertical and one (1) inch equals fifty (50) feet horizontal. 
(Prior code § 93-7) 
12.04.080 - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be liable to a fine of not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00), and upon failure to pay the fine, to imprisonment for a term not in excess of ninety (90) days, at the discretion of the judge hearing the case. 
(Prior code § 93-8) 
Article 2 - Regulations for Construction 

12.04.090 - Compliance with specifications of engineer. 
    All curbs, sidewalks, gutters, driveways or driveway aprons in or upon an accepted or public street in the borough shall be constructed or installed in accordance with the specifications of the borough engineer, which specifications are incorporated herein by reference. 
(Prior code § 93-11) 
12.04.100 - Permits-Application-Issuance-Fees. 
    No curb, sidewalk, gutter, driveway or driveway apron installation shall be undertaken unless a curb and sidewalk permit is issued by the construction code official. All applications for permits shall be made to the borough clerk of the borough, said permits shall be issued by the construction code official, and the required fees shall be paid as follows: 
A.  For each permit for the construction of a new sidewalk, curb, gutter, driveway or driveway apron, ten dollars ($10.00) for one hundred (100) linear feet, or any portion thereof. 
B.  For each permit for breaking existing curb, sidewalk, gutter, driveway or driveway apron, construction or repair, five dollars ($5.00). 
(Prior code § 93-12) 
12.04.110 - Pouring of concrete. 
    No new concrete or other construction material shall be poured until: 
A.  The borough engineer has set the curbline and graded at the site where necessary. 
B.  The permit is issued by the construction code official. 
C.  It shall be the responsibility of the permit holder to notify the borough engineer. 
D.  The permit referred to above is issued to: 
1.  The owner of property upon or in front of which the work is to be done, provided that such owner is to perform the work himself; or 
2.  A contractor qualified to do curb and sidewalk work. 
(Prior code § 93-13) 
12.04.120 - Protection from damage. 
    All work is to be protected from vandalism and damage by traffic or other causes by lighting and barricading said work area. All work damaged from whatever cause during the course of construction must be repaired or removed by the permit holder within fourteen (14) days of notification by the construction code official. 
(Prior code § 93-14) 
12.04.130 - Driveways constructed near street corners. 
    Where the permit holder plans to construct a new driveway, the entrance to which is to be within forty (40) feet of a street corner, no permit shall issue until the mayor and council have reviewed the plans and determined that such driveway entrance will not create a traffic hazard. 
(Prior code § 93-15) 
12.04.140 - Safety requirements. 
    During construction, barricades and warning lights must be placed at the site. 
(Prior code § 93-16) 
12.04.150 - Provisions nonapplicable. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to any work to be performed by the borough or any other governmental body. 
(Prior code § 93-17) 
12.04.160 - Furnishing of grades and specifications. 
    All grades and specifications shall be furnished by the borough engineer at the expense of the adjoining landowner at the following fees: 
A.  Charge for inspection, twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per visit. 
B.  Charge for field design and layout, seventy-five dollars ($75.00) per hour. 
C.  Plan review for grading, fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(Prior code § 93-18) 
12.04.170 - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) in the discretion of a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Prior code § 93-18.1) 
Article 3 - Paving and Resurfacing Permits 

12.04.180 - Compliance with requirements. 
    Before any area within the borough, other than public streets or sidewalks, is blacktopped, paved, macadamized, stoned, or in any way altered from its natural topography so as might unreasonably interfere with surrounding lands, approval shall first be obtained as provided in section 12.04.200 of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 93-19) 
12.04.190 - Exception to provisions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to any driveway area to be paved in conjunction with a single-family residential dwelling, with the exception of a stone driveway. 
(Prior code § 93-20; Ord. No. 2001:10, § 1, 2001) 
12.04.200 - Permit application, fee and issuance. 
    The following rules and regulations shall govern any proceedings under the provisions of this article: 
A.  Application procedure for paving permit. 
1.  All applications shall be made to the construction official. 
2.  Upon receipt of an application, the construction official shall refer the application, together with all supporting documents, to the planning board with a copy to the borough engineer for their review and recommendations. 
3.  The planning board and borough engineer shall each complete a review of the application and thereupon submit their recommendations, within thirty (30) days of its submission, to the building inspector. The building inspector shall issue the required paving permit only upon affirmance of both the planning board and borough engineer. If either the planning board or borough engineer shall deny recommendation of the application for a paving permit, the applicant shall be provided a written statement setting forth the reasons for such disapproval. 
4.  Appeal may be taken to the borough council; and by majority vote, the borough council may, after hearing upon notice to the parties, direct that the building inspector issue the required paving permit. 
B.  Application details. All applications shall at least include the following information: 
1.  Elevation of the lands. 
2.  The applicant's present, as well as intended, use of the land. 
3.  The physical composition of the material to be utilized for the proposed change, as well as the dimensions of the area of change. 
4.  A general description of the use and elevation of the lands which are contiguous to the land of the applicant. 
5.  Grading and drainage plans, including the final elevation of the applicant's land vis-a-vis the surrounding lands. 
6.  Planting and landscaping plans. 
7.  Natural features such as preservable trees, springs, watercourses and rock outcroppings, soil types and conditions, foundation characteristics, elevation of water table and the extent of manmade landfill. 
C.  Each application shall be accompanied by a fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) to cover the cost incurred by the borough in the review and processing of the application. 
D.  Application procedure for residential stone driveways. 
1.  All applications shall be made to the construction official. 
a.  Applicants must submit a diagram showing the location of the proposed stone driveway on parcel in relation to existing drives and structures. 
b.  Details must be shown as to the depth of the stone, and the material being used to block weed growth beneath the stone bed. 
c.  A border of brick, stone payers, garden ties, or similar material must be shown to act as a border to hold the stone bed in the desired location. 
d.  Concrete must be used in the borough right-of-way between the sidewalk and the curb. 
2.  Upon receipt of an application, the construction official shall refer the application, together with all the supporting documents to the administrative official for their review and recommendations. 
3.  The administrative official shall complete a review of the application and thereupon submit their recommendations within ten (10) calendar days of its submission to the construction official. The construction official shall issue the required stone driveway permit only upon affirmance of the administrative official. If the administrative official shall deny the recommendation of the application for a paving permit, the applicant shall be provided a written statement setting forth the reason for such a disapproval. 
4.  There will be no permit fee charged for residential stone driveway applications or permits. 
(Prior code § 93-21; Ord. No. 2001:10, § 2, 2001) 
12.04.210 - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be liable to a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment for a term not in excess of ninety (90) days. 
(Prior code § 93-22) 
Chapter 12.08 - EXCAVATIONS[1] 
Sections: 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2015:13, §§ 1, 2, adopted Oct. 13, 2015, repealed former Ch. 12.08., §§ 12.08.010-12.08.190, in its entirety and enacted new provisions as herein set out. Former Ch. 12.08 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the prior code, §§ 57-1--57-19; Ord. No. 2001:09, 2001. Section numbering has been modified by the editor to conform to the format used in this Code. 

12.08.010 - Definitions. 
    The following words, when used in this chapter, shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section except in those instances where the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
    "Applicant" means any person who makes an application for a permit. 
    "Borough" means the Borough of Stratford, County of Camden, State of New Jersey. 
    "Clerk" means the clerk of said municipality or his or her duly authorized deputy. 
    "Emergency" means any unforeseen circumstance or occurrence, the existence of which constitutes a clear and immediate danger to persons or properties. 
    "Engineer" means the person duly appointed borough engineer, his or her authorize deputy, representative or inspector. 
    "Permittee" means any person who has been issued a permit and is obligated to fulfill all the terms of this chapter. 
    "Person" means any natural person, partnership, firm, association, utility, corporation or authority created pursuant to statute. Whenever used in any section prescribing and imposing a penalty, the term "person" as applied to associations shall mean the partners and members thereof, and as applied to corporations, the officers thereof. 
    "Standard specifications" means the New Jersey State Highway Department Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction, 2007. 
    "Street" means the public street, public easement, public right-of-way, public highway, public way or public road accepted or maintained by the borough, and any state or county road over which the borough may have acquired jurisdiction by agreement. 
(Ord. No. 2015-13, § 2(Att.), 10-13-2015) 
12.08.020 - Permit required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to tear up, dig into, break up, displace or excavate any of the streets, sidewalks, curbs or gutters in the borough without first obtaining a permit from the borough clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2015-13, § 2(Att.), 10-13-2015) 
12.08.030 - Application for permit. 
A.  The application for a permit to make an opening or excavation in any street shall be in writing, dated and signed by the applicant, and shall state the road or street proposed to be opened or excavated and the object and purposes thereof, and shall also indicate the exact location, by length, width and depth, of said intended excavation. The application for permit shall include a detailed restoration plan conforming to the requirements of section 12.08.140. 
B.  In cases where the proposed opening involves construction of a longitudinal pipe main serving more than one (1) property, the borough may also require the applicant to submit plans showing the information required above and also the relationship of the proposed installation to the existing pavement, other utilities, the street right-of-way lines and any other physical features which might be affected by the proposed construction. 
C.  In cases where an applicant proposes multiple road openings on the same street, the borough may require final restoration to be a complete mill and overlay if the aggregate of the openings exceeds ten (10) percent of the roadway surface area. 
(Ord. No. 2015-13, § 2(Att.), 10-13-2015) 
12.08.040 - Deposits prior to issuance of permits. 
A.  Before the issuance of any such permit, the applicant shall deposit with the clerk of the borough the following amounts: 
1.  A minimum deposit of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) in cash or certified check, which shall cover an excavation no larger than thirty (30) square feet in area. 
2.  A minimum deposit of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) in cash or certified check, which shall cover any excavations greater than thirty (30) square feet in area, but no larger than fifty (50) square feet in area. 
3.  An additional amount for all street openings in excess of fifty (50) square feet, to be computed as follows: 
a.  Paved streets, including concrete pavements or bituminous concrete pavement on concrete or macadam base, one dollar ($1.00) per square foot. 
b.  Paved streets, including bituminous concrete pavement on gravel base, seventy-five cents ($0.75) per square foot. 
c.  Surface-treated streets, including bituminous surface treatment on gravel or macadam base, and also including bituminous mixed-in-place streets, fifty cents ($0.50) per square foot. 
d.  Gravel streets with no treatment or pavement, twenty-five cents ($0.25) per square foot. 
4.  An additional amount, based on the unit prices in the preceding subsection, if the area actually excavated exceeds that estimated at the time application was made. 
B.  The amount deposited shall be retained by the borough for a period of eighteen (18) months from the date of the reconstruction of the road, to guarantee the proper performance of the work done by the applicant and the maintenance thereof in good condition by the applicant for said eighteen-month period. 
(Ord. No. 2015-13, § 2(Att.), 10-13-2015) 
12.08.050 - Permit fees. 
    In addition to the above deposit, the applicant shall pay a non-returnable fee to be used to pay the cost of personnel employed to process the application and permit and to inspect the work performed as follows: 
Resident - A nonreturnable fee in the amount of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for the first twenty (20) square feet or part thereof of any opening and five dollars ($5.00) for each additional ten (10) square feet or part thereof up to two hundred (200) square feet. Business - A nonreturnable fee in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00) for the first twenty (20) square feet or part thereof of any opening and ten dollars ($10.00) for each additional ten (10) square feet or part thereof up to two hundred (200) square feet. Public Utilities- The nonrefundable fee shall be calculated in accordance with section 12.80.060.  
  
    In the case of openings which exceed two hundred (200) square feet, if at any time it becomes evident that the fees are or will be insufficient to cover the cost, the permittee shall pay to the clerk such additional fees certified by the borough engineer as required to meet the cost of the processing and inspection. 
    If the roadway in which the street opening is being made is less than five (5) years old since it was last paved and improved the fee will be five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) paid by all applicants for any permit for each opening or excavation to any public street, roadway or highway in the Borough of Stratford. The repair work for the closing of the street opening shall to allow for proper stabilization and surface to include the use of infrared technology on joints within the excavation. 
(Ord. No. 2015-13, § 2(Att.), 10-13-2015) 
12.08.060 - Guaranty bonds. 
A.  Private applicants. When the amount of the deposit, as determined under section 12.80.040, would exceed two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) the applicant may, at his or her option, furnish a guaranty bond with corporate surety for the full amount of such deposit instead of making the proposed street opening, backfill same and restore the pavement in accordance with requirements of the borough and maintain same for a period of eighteen (18) months from the date of the resurfacing of said road. 
B.  Public utilities. When the applicant is a public utility as defined by the statutes of the State of New Jersey, the borough may accept in lieu of the required deposit and fees previously set forth herein, a guaranty bond to the borough in the sum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00). The public utility must also pay a non-returnable fee to be used to pay the cost of personnel employed process the application and permit and to inspect the work performed in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the first twenty (20) square feet or part thereof of any opening and fifty dollars ($50.00) for each addition fifteen (15) square feet or part thereof up to two hundred (200) square feet. In those cases where the borough engineer, upon inspection, determines that the opening, based upon his or her experience and experience and expertise, will be one out of the ordinary due to the underground conditions or work involved, or where the proposed opening involves construction of a longitudinal pipe main serving more than one (1) property, or in any case where the area to be opened exceeds five hundred (500) square feet, or where multiple openings exceed ten (10) percent of the roadway surface, applicant shall also pay the actual cost of inspection or inspections. Such bond shall guarantee payment of the amount that would have been deposited in the event of failure of the applicant to comply with this chapter. Such bond shall guarantee that the public utility will make the proposed street opening, backfill the same and restore the pavement in accordance with the requirements of the borough. Such bond shall also include a thirty-six-month guaranty. The borough, at its option, may accept a corporate bond. Where the estimated cost of restoration exceeds fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00), the public utility shall supply an additional bond to cove such expenses. Said bond shall not be considered to be filed until it is approved and accepted by resolution of the borough council. In the event that, after proper filing of a bond by the public utility as aforesaid, said public utility shall fail to abide strictly by the provisions of this chapter, the borough council may, by resolution and without prior notice to the public utility, revoke any privileges for street opening which may have previously been granted under its guaranty bond, and revoke said bond and return it to the public utility, and require cash deposits for all future street openings made by said public utility, as well as cash deposits for all openings not properly restored as of the date of revocation of said bond. 
(Ord. No. 2015-13, § 2(Att.), 10-13-2015) 
12.08.070 - Waiver of requirements for certain borough authorities. 
    Nothing contained herein shall pertain when the applicant is a contractor performing work for the borough or for the borough sewerage authority. 
(Ord. No. 2015-13, § 2(Att.), 10-13-2015) 
12.08.080 - Waiver of requirements where suitable guaranties for construction exist. 
    When the applicant is a subdivider or site plan applicant, where escrow funds or other suitable guaranty for complete reconstruction of an existing road have been provided and where proper approvals for all proposed work have been obtained, the borough council may waive the requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2015-13, § 2(Att.), 10-13-2015) 
12.08.090 - Work to be completed in an expeditious manner. 
    Any person making any opening or excavation in any street in the borough shall carry out the work as expeditiously as possible and in such manner as to cause the least possible public inconveniences and to permit the use of the sidewalk by pedestrians, the roadway by vehicles and the flow of water along the gutters. 
(Ord. No. 2015-13, § 2(Att.), 10-13-2015) 
12.08.100 - Adequate warning and protection required. 
    All openings, diggings excavations, piles of material, equipment and barricades, including earth, dirt and stone or other materials removed from the excavation, shall be carefully guarded at all times to prevent accidents, and a sufficient number of lighted lanterns, flares or torches shall be maintained between sunset and sunrise by the contractor or persons to whom such permit has been granted, to designate such openings or obstruction during the hours of darkness. Whereas any excavation or trench is to extend across any road or street, only one-half (1/2) of the same shall be made at one (1) time, and it shall be properly backfilled before the other one-half (1/2) is excavated so as not to interfere with traffic. 
(Ord. No. 2015-13, § 2(Att.), 10-13-2015) 
12.08.110 - Protection of property during work. 
    All existing pavements, road surfaces, sidewalks, curbs, gutters, pipes, manholes, drains, conduits or other installations or fixtures and property likely to be injured, damaged or destroyed shall be properly protected by the person doing any work for which a permit has been granted, during the time when such work is being performed. 
(Ord. No. 2015-13, § 2(Att.), 10-13-2015) 
12.08.120 - Time limit for commencement and completion of work. 
    The work on any opening to be made under any such permit shall be commenced within ten (10) days from the date of such permit and the work prosecuted with due diligence to its completion. The permittee shall provide a twenty-four-hour notification to the borough clerk prior to opening a road in order to schedule inspection personnel. If for any reason work is not commenced within said period of ten (10) days, the applicant shall present the permit to the borough clerk, who shall thereupon either return the deposit required under section 12.80.040 this chapter above or extend the time for the beginning of the said work for another period of ten (10) days be endorsement on the permit, and no permit so extended shall be valid unless the work thereunder is commenced within ten (10) days from the date of such endorsement. If work is not commenced within the extended period of time, the deposit required under section 12.080.4 this chapter shall be returned to the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 2015-13, § 2(Att.), 10-13-2015) 
12.08.130 - Opening restricting vehicular traffic. 
    In the case of any opening which restricts vehicular traffic to less than two (2), ten-foot wide travel lanes, excavation and backfill shall be made within a single eight-hour period, except under special occasions or circumstances where underground conditions or structures warrant a longer period of time. In other cases, it shall be made within one (1) week's time, except where underground conditions or structures warrant a longer period of time. Street openings shall be resurfaced within the period of time designated by the borough engineer at the time he or she inspects the backfilling operation, having due regard to the type of street involved and the volume of vehicular traffic which uses the same. Prior to resurfacing, the backfill shall be maintained in order to prevent depressions or bumps in the street surfaces and suitable material shall be applied thereto to keep down dust. 
(Ord. No. 2015-13, § 2(Att.), 10-13-2015) 
12.080.140 - Restoration. 
A.  Whenever any street, sidewalk, curb or gutter is broken up or excavated, it shall be restored to its proper condition as soon as practicable by the person having broken up or excavated it, at his or her own expenses, to the satisfaction of the borough engineer. 
B.  Any person making any opening or excavation shall resurface all such openings and backfill them in accordance with the following procedure, so the roadway or surface is replaced in a condition as near as possible as it was prior to the opening or excavation: 
1.  All fill material shall be deposited in layers not exceeding twelve (12) inches and each layer shall be rammed or tamped with pneumatic or power-driven mechanical tampers approved by the borough engineer or his/her designee. 
2.  Broken or crushed stone to be used in replacing the stone base shall be cast in separate piles and kept clean and separate from other excavation material and shall be carefully replaced to a minimum thickness of eight (8) inches. The stone base shall be tamped and keyed with mineral filler. 
3.  When filled, the trench shall be level and flush with the finished grade of the street adjacent to the opening. A temporary patch shall be constructed by the permittee, consisting of two (2) inches compacted thickness of cold patch material, Grade A or Grade B, as defined in the standard specifications. The temporary patch shall be constructed within twenty-four (24) hours after tamping of the backfill. Permittee shall, to the satisfaction of the borough engineer or his/her designee, maintain the surface of the trench until permanent restoration is made. 
4.  No permittee shall commence permanent surface restoration of any street until the engineer, his or her representative or the borough road foreman deemed that settlement of the subsurface is complete and the area properly prepared for restoration. All foundations shall be restored to a width of six (6) inches wider than the width of the restored foundation and six (6) inches longer than the length of the restored foundation. All foundations and surfaces shall be restored with the same type of material and to the same depth as existed prior to making the excavation, in accordance with the requirements of the standard specifications. The permittee shall furnish all materials, equipment, tools and labor to properly construct a permanent pavement to match the existing pavement in thickness or a six-inch (compacted thickness). Permanent Pavement Course which is greater to those areas of the paved roadways or shoulders where the original pavement has been removed, disturbed or destroyed by the construction activity. The work shall consist of preparation of the subgrade, retrimming the edge of trench and placement of the permanent pavement course, using: 
a.  The materials and composition of mixture shall conform to the requirements of Section 903 and 904 of the New Jersey Department of Transportation Standard Specifications of 2007. 
b.  The permanent pavement restoration shall consist of bituminous base course to match existing in thickness, or four (4) inches (compacted thickness) of Bituminous Stabilized Base Course, Mix 1-2. Top course shall be two (2) inches compacted thickness of Bituminous Concrete Surface Course Mix No. 1-5 or 1-4. 
5.  Permanent restoration with a concrete street of alley. 
a.  In a street or alley that has concrete sub-base, the trench or excavation shall be restored with gravel to match existing gravel subbase and four thousand (4,000) psi concrete with one-half (1/2) inch stone and fibermesh admixture to the depth to match existing concrete subbase, as specified in Section 305 of the NJ DOT Standard Specifications of 2007. 
b.  When the trench or excavation is within a street or alley that is constructed Entirely of concrete, the trench or excavation shall be restored using four thousand (4,000) psi Class B grey concrete with one-half (1/2) inch stone and fibermesh admixture to a grade to match existing concrete surface. In the event the ambient temperature warrants, the mix may include a one (1) percent or two (2) percent high-early admixture. 
6.  In cases where an applicant proposes multiple road openings on the same street, the borough may require final restoration of the surface course to include a complete mill and overlay if the aggregate of the opening exceeds ten (10) percent of the roadway surface area. Restoration of the foundation and base course shall meet the requirements of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2015-13, § 2(Att.), 10-13-2015) 
12.08.150 - Failure to properly excavate, backfill or restore. 
    In the event that the permittee shall fail to properly excavate, backfill or restore the street, sidewalk, curb or gutter involved to its proper condition as soon as practicable and within three (3) days after the service or mailing of a notice from the borough engineer, then the borough engineer may cause such restoration to be made and pay the cost thereof from said deposit, or, in case a bond has been filed in lieu of a cash deposit, the borough shall collect the cost of such restoration from the permittee. If, during such period of eighteen (18) months, or in the case of a public utility filing a guaranty bond, three-year, the filling of the opening shall require repairing and the permittee shall fail to make such repairs as are required within three (3) days after the service or mailing of a notice from the borough engineer so to do, then the borough engineer may cause such repairs to be made and pay the cost thereof from said deposit, or, in case a bond has been filed in lieu of a cash deposit, the borough shall collect the cost of such repairs from the permittee. When the work has been completed in accordance with the requirements and regulations as contained herein and as may from time to time be adopted by the borough to implement this chapter, the deposit, or such portion of the deposit which may remain, will be refunded to the permittee. 
(Ord. No. 2015-13, § 2(Att.), 10-13-2015) 
12.80.160 - Digging of ditches-Approval of engineer. 
A.  No ditch shall be dug within ten (10) feet of any street without first obtaining the approval of the engineer, which approval shall not be given unless, in his or her opinion, the ditch will not endanger the construction of the road which it will adjoin. 
B.  No existing ditch adjoining a street and within ten (10) feet thereof shall be excavated to a depth lower than that now existing without first obtaining the approval of the engineer, which approval shall not be given unless, in his or her opinion, the lowering of the depth of the ditch will not endanger the construction of the road which it adjoins. 
(Ord. No. 2015-13, § 2(Att.), 10-13-2015) 
12.80.170 - Street openings in emergencies. 
    In the event of an emergency where circumstances will not warrant delay to first secure a street opening permit, a street may be opened without a permit; provided, however, that such opening shall be confined in size to the area necessary to take care of the emergency. A street opening permit for said emergency opening, plus any additional area that it may be necessary to open, shall be secured before the close of business on the next business day of the borough following the opening. Each day's delay in securing the street opening permit following an emergency street opening shall be deemed a distinct and separate violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2015-13, § 2(Att.), 10-13-2015) 
12.08.180 - Insurance against claims. 
A.  The applicant shall maintain such insurance as will protect the applicant and the borough from claims under the Workmen's Compensation Act and from claims for damage to property and injury or death to persons. Such property damage insurance shall be written for not less than twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00), and for personal injuries or death, not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) per person and three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) per occurrence. 
B.  The applicant shall agree by acceptance and receipt of the permit to save and indemnify and keep harmless the borough against all liability claims from accidents to person or property arising from the road opening or reconstruction of the road, and to defend any suit that may be brought against the borough relating to the opening of the road or resurfacing of same. 
(Ord. No. 2015-13, § 2(Att.), 10-13-2015) 
12.08.190 - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person who shall violate any provisions of this chapter or any rule, regulation or standard promulgated hereunder shall, upon conviction, be liable to a penalty of not more than One thousand ($1,000.00) dollars or imprisonment in the county jail for a term not exceeding ninety (90) days, or both, in the discretion of the court. 
(Ord. No. 2015-13, § 2(Att.), 10-13-2015) 
Chapter 12.12 - SNOW AND ICE REMOVAL 
Sections: 

12.12.010 - Responsibility to remove snow and ice. 
A.  The owner or owners, occupant or occupants, tenant or tenants of premises abutting or bordering upon any street in the borough shall remove all snow and ice from the abutting sidewalks of such streets or, in the case of ice which may be so frozen as to make removal impracticable, shall cause the same to be thoroughly covered with sand, salt or other suitable materials within twelve (12) hours of daylight after the same shall fall or be formed thereon. 
B.  In case the building is occupied by more than one (1) family or business unit, then the tenant or occupant of the first floor or story thereof is hereby required to remove all snow and ice from such portion of the sidewalks or, in the case of ice which is impracticable to remove, cover the same with sand, salt or other suitable materials within twelve (12) hours of daylight after the same shall be formed or fall thereon. 
(Prior code § 93-23) 
12.12.020 - Throwing or placing of snow or ice upon streets. 
    No person, firm or corporation nor the owner, tenant or occupant of any premises abutting on any street shall throw, place or deposit any snow or ice into or upon any street in said borough, it being the intent and purpose of this provision to prohibit all persons from throwing, casting, placing or depositing snow and ice, which accumulated within the private property belonging to said person, upon the sidewalks or streets of the borough. 
(Prior code § 93-24) 
12.12.030 - Procedure upon nonremoval. 
    In case such snow or ice shall not be removed from such sidewalks or shall be cast, deposited thereon or placed upon said sidewalks or said street by the owner or owners, tenant or tenants, occupant or occupants of any said premises as provided in sections 12.12.010 and 12.12.020 of this chapter, the same shall be removed forthwith and under the direction of the chief of police of the borough, and the cost of such removal as nearly as can be ascertained shall be certified by said chief of police to the governing body. The governing body shall examine such certification and, if found to be correct, shall cause such cost to be charged against such real estate so abutting or bordering upon such sidewalks, and the amount so charged shall forthwith become a lien and a tax upon such real estate or land and be added to, recorded and collected in the same way and manner as the taxes next to be levied and assessed upon such premises and shall bear interest and be enforced and collected by the same officers and in the same manner as other taxes. The imposition and collection of a fine or fines imposed by the provision of this chapter shall not constitute any bar to the right of the borough to collect the cost as certified for the removal of said snow or ice in the manner herein authorized. 
(Prior code § 93-25) 
12.12.040 - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment in the county jail for a period not exceeding ninety (90) days, or both. 
(Prior code § 93-26) 
12.12.050 - Statutory authority. 
    This chapter is adopted pursuant to the authority conferred by N.J.S.A. 40:65-12. 
(Prior code § 93-27) 
Chapter 12.16 - INTERSECTION SIGHT-LINE OBSTRUCTIONS 
Sections: 

12.16.010 - Cutting and removal of brush and hedges at intersections. 
    The owner or tenant of lands lying within the limits of the borough shall keep all brush, hedges and other plant life growing within ten (10) feet of any roadway and within twenty-five (25) feet of the intersection of two (2) roadways, cut to a height of not more than two and one-half (21/2) feet where it shall be necessary and expedient for the preservation of the public safety, within ten (10) days after notice to cut the same. 
(Prior code § 93-9) 
12.16.020 - Work by borough-Costs.
